GPII-3707: Move keyring from global to infra_region
content.body:
**Rendered docs: https://github.com/mrtyler/gpii-infra/blob/gpii-3707-regionalism/gcp/README.md**

Requires https://github.com/gpii-ops/exekube/pull/49, which can be safely merged on its own.
- [x] Merged and deployed

I'm finalizing documentation and the rollout plan but I think I'm done with the implementation, hence no WIP label.

### Changes
I tried to make targeted commits but there was a hard-to-remove detour where I thought I needed to change the Keyring name based on Region. Anyway, the main themes, ordered roughly by batches of commits:

1. Small cleanups, including removing Stepan's hack for GPII-3568. I think Stepan is removing that in one of his in-flight branches, but it was causing me trouble so I removed it here as well.
2. Refactor secrets.rb and its call sites in rake land. Use Keyrings in `infra_region` instead of `global`. Add some basic unit tests. I'm not a huge fan of classes but:
   * This is a classic use case for a class: data bundled with methods for working with that data
   * Dealing with environment variables in unit tests is kind of annoying (see vars_spec.rb).
   * I think instance variables (set via constructer parameters) are a more natural fit than environment variables, and they declutter the rake file a bit compared with passing things like `project_id` in every time.
3. Add some helpers to facilitate migration from the global keyring, and for moving between regions.

### Alternative approach
My main goal was to enable us to run GPII Cloud environments in any region. I have been able to do that in my tests, but the current approach has some downsides:
* It requires some extra `terraform import` steps because KMS Keyrings are indestructible and Keys have an unusual lifecycle
   * I think moving from region to region will be rare in practice
   * I've added some rudimentary automation for this, `rake import_keyring`
* Each environment has a single tfstate bucket in Multi-Region `US`, no matter in which Region the environment really runs

I have considered, but not yet tested, an alternative approach with a tfstate bucket in each region where we might wish to run an environment. This avoids the `terraform import` steps because tfstate in us-east1 can always point to the keyring in us-east1. I haven't pursued this avenue because:
* We need to migrate off of `global` Keyrings regardless, so something like this PR and its rollout plan will be necessary
* tfstate buckets are managed by common, so we'd need to create them ahead of time for each environment X region we want to have available
* Multiple tfstate buckets would allow (in fact, require) `apply_infra` resources (e.g. VPCs, public IPs) in each Region. This is a small waste and a small amount of extra clutter
* Multiple tfstate buckets would allow users to accidentally run two environments at once (e.g. one in us-east1, one in us-central1)
* DNS is still a singleton. The default behavior with multiple tfstate buckets would be "last one wins", which is not so bad but nonetheless adds a potential source of confusion.

### Exported logs
We have a decision to make about existing exported logs for stg and prd:
1. Delete them - how much value do they have?
1. Leave them alone - it is theoretically possible to decrypt and read the logs later as long as we are careful not to destroy the global Key used to write them
1. Re-encrypt them in place - this is the safest, but most expensive option
   * I think we can use a modified version of `rotate_tfstate_key` to accomplish this, but I haven't tested it yet.
- [x] Decided to keep prd logs

### Rollback plan
The basic idea is to undo the rollout by re-importing the `global` Keyring and Keys and re-encrypting data using the Old Keys. The steps here are for pointing the environment back to the Old Keyring. Other steps may be needed as well, depending on when the rollout was abandoned.

1. Revert this PR (i.e. go back to Old version of code)
   * The associated Exekube PR and resulting image may remain
1. Update gpii-infra to Old version
1. `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
1. `rake sh`
1. `unset GOOGLE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`
1. `cd /project/live/$ENV/secret-mgmt`
1. Replace the New Keyring and Keys with the Old Keyring and Keys:
```
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_key_ring.key_ring
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_key_ring.key_ring projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[0]
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[0] projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring/cryptoKeys/default
terragrunt state rm module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[1]
terragrunt import module.gcp-secret-mgmt.google_kms_crypto_key.encryption_keys[1] projects/$TF_VAR_project_id/locations/global/keyRings/keyring/cryptoKeys/gcp-stackdriver-export
```

### Rollout plan
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for dev-doe (skipping some steps since dev-doe is an ephemeral cluster), which will be deployed into a new region (us-east4) as a test case
- [x] Notify cloud-developers of required actions (see below)
- [x] Merge this PR, which will eventually run CI for dev-doe.
- [x] Verify everything looks correct. In particular, look out for changes to Keyrings and changes to the tfstate bucket as part of common-stg
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for stg
- [x] Promote common-prd
- [x] Verify everything looks correct in stg
   * plan-all in prd will fail, because migration steps haven't run there yet
- [x] Complete migration steps (below) for prd
- [x] Re-run plan-all in prd. Verify everything looks correct
- [x] Promote prd
- [x] Re-encrypt prd's exported logs (see below)

#### Migration steps

"Old" refers to the tip of master / the latest deployed infrastructure from before this PR (i.e. with Keyrings and Keys in the "global" Region). "New" refers to code / infrastructure after this PR is merged.

1. Update to latest version of gpii-infra
1. `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
1. `rake update_exekube`
1. Replace the Old Keyring and Keys with the New Keyring and Keys:
   * `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake import_keyring`
   * EDIT: This didn't work in stg (and won't in prd) because there is no Keyring to import from us-central1. So we must create it.
      * Manually run `terragrunt state rm` commands to prevent globaly Kerying and Keys from being destroyed
      * Use the `terragrunt plan` steps below to verify that ONLY new Keyring and Keys are CREATED (no Old buckets or Keys destroyed)
      * Run `terragrunt apply`
1. Verify that `terragrunt plan` doesn't want to make any changes
   * `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake sh` and then inside shell:
   * `unset GOOGLE_ENCRYPTION_KEY`
   * `cd /project/live/$ENV/secret-mgmt`
   * `terragrunt plan`
   * Exit shell
1. `TF_VAR_decrypt_with_key_from_region=global rake rotate_secrets_key`
1. `rake rotate_secrets_key"[gcp-stackdriver-export]"`
1. `rake` (perhaps via CI)
   * Should be mostly a no-op.
1. Fix encryption for exported logs bucket (see below)
1. Verify logs exported both before and after the migration are readable
   * [Go to bucket](https://console.cloud.google.com/storage/browser/gpii-gcp-prd-exported-logs?project=gpii-gcp-prd&authuser=1&organizationId=247149361674)
   * Navigate to some Old logs. Verify that you can view them (no KMS error)
   * Navigate to some New logs -- you may have to wait up to an hour for new logs to be exported. Verify that you can view them (no KMS error)
1. Disable (do *NOT* destroy!) Keys in `global` Keyring

#### Email to cloud-developers
```
Subject: New regions available for dev envs (action required)


Hi cloud developers,

Good news: It is now possible to create a dev environment in any Google Cloud region![1][2] Instructions are here:
https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/master/gcp/README.md#i-want-to-spin-up-my-dev-environment-in-a-different-region

Bad news: You must take action -- even if you are happy to stay in your current region -- to keep your cluster up-to-date. (Please do this migration separately, before trying out a new region. :))

If you are able to destroy your environment, the process is pretty standard:
* `cd gpii-infra/gcp/live/dev`
* `rake destroy`
* Update gpii-infra to latest master
* `rake update_exekube`
* `rake destroy_hard`[3]
* `rake`

If you are not able to destroy your environment, you can safely migrate an existing environment. It's a little more complex, so you may want to consult Ops before pursuing this route:
* See "Rollout plan: Migration steps" in https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/329.

Please ping us in #ops if you have questions or any trouble!

Thanks,
the ops team


[1] I haven't tested anything outside of the US. Who will spin up the first GPII Cloud in Europe??

[2] Some infrastructure (the GCS Bucket where Terraform keeps its state) remains in the `US` multi-region.

[3] `destroy_hard` is a new helper command for destroying even more stuff related to your environment, like Terraform state and secrets.
```

#### Re-encrypt exported logs
1. After the migration step `rake rotate_secrets_key"[gcp-stackdriver-export]"`, New exported logs will be readable, but Old exported logs will not. This is because Terraform deletes the IAM binding that allows GS to access the Old Key when adding the IAM binding for the New Key.
1. Manually add a binding for the Old Key:
   * `rake sh`
   * Get the appropriate Serviceaccount user and Role from the New Key:
      * `gcloud kms keys get-iam-policy --location $TF_VAR_infra_region --keyring keyring gcp-stackdriver-export`
   * Use this info to add the same binding to the Old Key:
      * `gcloud kms keys add-iam-policy-binding gcp-stackdriver-export --location global --keyring $TF_VAR_keyring_name --member serviceAccount:service-111111111111@gs-project-accounts.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/cloudkms.cryptoKeyEncrypterDecrypter`
1. Rewrite everything in the exported logs bucket using the New Key:
   * `gsutil -m rewrite -r -k gs://${TF_VAR_project_id}-exported-logs`
1. Remove manually added binding
   * `gcloud kms keys remove-iam-policy-binding gcp-stackdriver-export --location global --keyring $TF_VAR_keyring_name --member serviceAccount:service-111111111111@gs-project-accounts.iam.gserviceaccount.com --role roles/cloudkms.cryptoKeyEncrypterDecrypter`
comments:
Looks good, kudos for the tests & like like the refactor.

> I'd like to move forward with the current design. No matter what we do with the tfstate bucket, we will do it in a separate PR as I think this PR already has enough moving parts.

Makes sense. I would still consider unique names for keyrings (I think it'll make our lives easier).

Thanks for thorough description 👍, it helps ;). I'm commenting on the text of PR only so far:

> an alternative approach with a tfstate bucket in each region where we might wish to run an environment

What about creating the bucket in only the desired region (this would be parametrized in the common code) and then creating the cluster and all the resources in the corresponding region? (info about the region can be retrieved for example by using TF `remote_state`) That would avoid having unused resources and solve most/all the issues mentioned.

In general I would definitely prefer to have tfstate bucket in the same region as the rest of resources.

> We have a decision to make about existing exported logs for stg and prd:

As discussed, I'm ok to loose log in non-prod env. For production I would try to preserve those - i think it should be achieveavble using `gsutil` - unless the old key material is destroyed. gsutil shoul be able to read those logs and by running `cp` save & reencrypt them with the new key/keyring (`gsutil cp` between 2 GCS buckets should work directly without actually pulling/pushing data via the node running the command).

Stepan, I'm afraid I don't understand your suggestion:

> What about creating the bucket in only the desired region (this would be parametrized in the common code) 

There is no single "desired region". The goal of this feature is to make it possible to run infrastructure in any region. So AFAICT we must either "migrate" back and forth, updating tfstate each time, or we must have dedicated tfstate in each region.

> and then creating the cluster and all the resources in the corresponding region? (info about the region can be retrieved for example by using TF remote_state) 

We do (with this PR) create the cluster and all resources in the specified region (i.e. the value of `TF_VAR_infra_region`. The only thing that is hardcoded to us-central1 is the tfstate bucket itself.

> That would avoid having unused resources and solve most/all the issues mentioned.

I don't see how.

Re: exported logs:

Due to [an incident](https://pad.gpii.net/mypads/?/mypads/group/gpii-infrastructure-standups-lix4njm/pad/view/postmortems-but4nne#L255), we have already destroyed the exported stg logs.

For prd logs, we agreed to rewrite them and keep them. I am figuring out how best to do this.

> There is no single "desired region". The goal of this feature is to make it possible to run infrastructure in any region. So AFAICT we must either "migrate" back and forth, updating tfstate each time, or we must have dedicated tfstate in each region.

So where I was going was that the tfstate region, and therefore the region for the cluster, would be specified in common code. That way you can create the bucket in the region where the cluster will land.

So you would still be able to have cluster in any region, but should you would want to change the region, you would have to rerun common.

Passing the desired region to all the places that need it is not the problem. The problem is keeping tfstate files in sync with cloud resources. I also don't like forcing developers to ask for help if they want to change regions.

I'd like to move forward with the current design. No matter what we do with the tfstate bucket, we will do it in a separate PR as I think this PR already has enough moving parts.

LGTM, for now. 

I can not see very clear the advantages of having a bucket per region, and I can see some pain every time that we need to move from one to other. I would leave this PR as is, and see how we go. New approaches can be implemented in the future if we need them.

> I would still consider unique names for keyrings (I think it'll make our lives easier).

This would avoid the need to import existing Keyrings when starting fresh. But Keyrings are indestructible, so we would accrue many discarded Keyrings over time. I think Sergey and I discussed this option and abandoned it for that reason.

Ok, I've done more testing, fixed a couple bugs, and updated the docs and rollout plan. My plan is to deploy this tomorrow morning unless there are objections.

The last bit I need to work out is re-encrypting the exported logs. I don't think it will be a big deal, but I keep forgetting to test it before deleting my environment and all the exported logs in it :). This step is not in the critical path, so it can be delayed a bit while I get the rest of the changes out.
Latest changes LGTM
Would it make sense to include the region in the name of the keyring? `"keyring-${var.infra_region}" maybe? This should eventually allow multiple keyrings in different regions to co-exist.
It turns out that Keyrings in different regions need not have unique names. My dev environment has four Keyrings in different regions, all named "keyring".
ok then, I did not know that :), thanks for info

content.title: GPII-3917 Fix issues on deployment
content.body:
Changes of this repository:

1. Some path of the buckets were not properly set because the first check of the script fails.
1. Some roles were missing for the SA that is used to access the destination buckets.  The first time that CloudBuild runs tries to set all the permissions by itself. Of course, this is not possible in our environment because the SA that it uses is very limited. So we are setting the permissions instead.
1. STG and PRD don't have the default network that we have in DEV, so the command has been modified to use a particular region, just to store the images before they are sent to the destination bucket.
1. When we change the region, the working bucket used by the Daisy scripts changes.
comments:
LGTM. I think it makes more sense for users to specify a bucket name and we add `gs://` and other syntax decorations in the code.

I know you're fixing some bugs so feel free to merge this as-is. However I have some questions.

> STG and PRD don't have the default network that we have in DEV, so the command has been modified to use a particular region

Can you say more about this? It seems undesirable.

Reviewing some environments:
* Alfredo and I have a `default` network that mentions every worldwide region
* Stepan has two networks (`test` and `work`) that mention every worldwide region
* stg, prd, and user dev envs I looked at did not have a `default` network.

I think this is maybe a bug but probably a leftover result from an older version of the code that should be manually cleaned up.

My main concern is the wide permissions given to Cloud Build. IMHO this should be applied only on the required service account, instead of the whole project (and all accounts within).

> STG and PRD don't have the default network that we have in DEV, so the command has been modified to use a particular region, just to store the images before they are sent to the destination bucket.

The default network is not expected to exist and should not be relied upon - https://github.com/gpii-ops/exekube/blob/b68c0e0e803356b3814aa92fd69e66d777d3ed41/modules/gke-network/main.tf#L87
I'm merging this just to stabilize the backup-exporter. The rest of the comments will be addressed in a different PR.

I'm a little suspicious of the coupling of network/subnet names here and in exekube's gke-network module. The only solution I can think of would be to make those names variables and plumb them everywhere; this may be overkill for a couple of hardcoded values that are unlikely to change.

I'm a bit more suspicious of the hardcoded region. Perhaps this doesn't matter (though it seems like we could incur more data transfer costs than necessary if we do it "wrong") or is more complex than it looks (e.g. I'm not sure I understand the comment about "The Daisy bucket can use a different name depending on the zone where the Cloudbuild runs") but could we use TF_VAR_infra_region or something here instead?
This seems very wide permission - the Cloud Build can now use any service account. Perhaps this should be set only on the desired service account and not on the whole project?
Same as above - seems too open.

I can not find which permissions `gcloud compute images export` needs for what. All that I can find is in the doc:
https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/images/export

And also in the errors that are raised in the logs when something fails:

https://console.cloud.google.com/logs/viewer?interval=JUMP_TO_TIME&project=gpii-gcp-stg&authuser=1&organizationId=247149361674&minLogLevel=0&expandAll=false&timestamp=2019-08-05T16%3A48%3A24.000000000Z&customFacets&limitCustomFacetWidth=false&advancedFilter=resource.type%3D%22k8s_container%22%0Aresource.labels.location%3D%22us-central1%22%0Aresource.labels.project_id%3D%22gpii-gcp-stg%22%0Aresource.labels.pod_name%3D%22backup-exporter-1565034300-jzcbb%22%0Aresource.labels.cluster_name%3D%22k8s-cluster%22%0Aresource.labels.container_name%3D%22backup-container%22%0Aresource.labels.namespace_name%3D%22backup-exporter%22%0Atimestamp%3D%222019-08-05T19%3A45%3A13.853317678Z%22%0AinsertId%3D%22zp48fzah6zyne0y7x%22&scrollTimestamp=2019-08-05T19%3A46%3A15.930421706Z&dateRangeStart=2019-08-05T15%3A48%3A24.000Z&dateRangeUnbound=forwardInTime

Where we can see that the command failed because the `gke-cluster-pod-bckp-exporter@gpii-gcp-stg.iam.gserviceaccount.com` was not able to grant the privileges to the cloudbuild SA:
```
INFO: Adding [serviceAccount:774516236737@cloudbuild.gserviceaccount.com] to [roles/iam.serviceAccountTokenCreator
```

The region and the network is not hardcoded now:
https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/480

The GCS "Daisy bucket" is something that the `gcloud compute images export` command creates automatically, among other things. In my dev environment where I had the default network, the name of the bucket was "[project_id]-daisy-bkt", when I set the network and thus the region in stg and prd, the `gcloud compute ...` tried to use "[project_id]-daisy-bkt-us" instead. Why? I don't know, I saw the error in the logs of the backup-exporter cronjob and changed the Terraform code to avoid it.

I realize of this "actions" performed by the `gcloud compute images export` command in the errors that it throws, because I was not able to find neither the code or the documentation about what this command does in the background. So the only way to use this command by a service account in our cloud is to run several times and try to recreate the same actions that it tries to do using Terraform code. This is why the implementation of the "backup exporter" it's being so frustrating and annoying. Every time that something changes, the command tries to do a new action that is not able to do. That happened:
- When the command was fired from a container with a SA instead of a normal terminal with owner permissions.
- When the destination bucket is not in the same project of the images
- When the default network was not available in the project where it runs
- When the destination/log/intermediate buckets do not have the proper permissions to store, list and delete files.
- etc

Links related:
[Documentation about the command](https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/images/export)
[Script that the VM created by cloud build executes](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/compute-image-tools/tree/master/daisy_workflows/export)
[Source code of the gce_export command](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/compute-image-tools/blob/master/cli_tools/gce_export/main.go)
[Sample of log of the daisy export](https://00e9e64bac5679d732287da770a4581ad5acdcf59d14dcdf92-apidata.googleusercontent.com/download/storage/v1/b/gpii-gcp-stg-daisy-bkt-us/o/daisy-image-export-20190806-11:14:08-dm1sh%2Flogs%2Fdaisy.log?qk=AD5uMEuYlp7UQ7DgP8G95AjxWtCwZviqn1SFhIcTuY15TXgeRaNfdruv3dKv_ArrlgxmDLzk3tjyh-eJz1QmE5EBvJtMxBskrb9iz1rggQl90KvPl5HP5GJDW6i5x9PXOMlxhx5uu-7PkQZLRzd5cF2uZPaRkj59WAu7XDLNs_1POpp5imDQ8OaIDY3nqaUwsVshBVkJeS3T8-sE5ud7Y8qiLtdDU-sCCGQXqv6SEMMc_1koLzopfupFZxH4lFVm5dXDRrkIistuxVGMb_dOvaLcVF6cfnJSSdn_HtqYqlNJMh7dhEXDAFQUmB71YOFzbLoauySwag9-cxGxtJVME-w9IqH3d2aFc3P9mkv5ObuXsURLkl3TpIZ14p1ID4f9qyNQ9VXpU9iFDUtbdraUvemuGwdGNfYSo-SgntL7FpG-BdosEA4YqHUD5Ts8dhYKEWcHittb_Ih-0RGHmA_LQG6XFrx2oY8V8nKQ1mbi0zYoZ-TWzAPjGxgkeYqrP3MBAzD1RTsVm4SQdq1Em6nVnIWZ65E-xBOjDNsOq_7MwVu1_yni-QadXc-cbSFPDAyYq0FCmekR4t5CRDgJUanWRHvY0QxdgkaTOWrAOnqezjoRZIRo-9OWd0-mE6KGhPAlMpbsIHOvi1X2Hg9dK0I4nzkPfIkZgiPI5xKH6Gm7QZTZOSm-x1pJUfhPWqEugrIZIHQ3J8CPtvke-9rEPMDlzfifnRytLZtTEJK6FlxpR0F8QVfirrvpjSRycgYfhAaJ-eiyPANYGHDL1LYi2q_EC1GbWVNmR9tkrMDus5E1jRtVfhbKfOckgGUekUKFWeOoZFWuUx9mQ9cdCUzh4g0BB27ACTo_f5wu4A)

> I can not find which permissions

@amatas the role itself (`roles/iam.serviceAccountUser`) is fine, but it should not be applied on the whole project, allowing Cloud build to use all service accounts in the project, but instead it should only be granted on individual service account (`gke-cluster-pod-bckp-exporter@..`), using the `google_service_account_iam_policy`  Terraform resource, and therefore allowing Cloud build to use only that particular account.

I guess I explained wrongly. Cloud build does not need the role (roles/iam.serviceAccountUser) to use the SA (gke-cluster-pod-bckp-exporter@..).

The (`gke-cluster-pod-bckp-exporter@..`) SA tries to set the IAM role (roles/iam.serviceAccountUser) at project level for the `cloud build SA` when the `gcloud` command is fired if it is not already set, but it fails because the (`gke-cluster-pod-bckp-exporter@..`) SA does not have `setIamPolicy` permission.

I guess that the `cloud build SA` needs to use another SA of the project, but I do not know what it is.

After some additional research we discover that the command `gcloud compute images export` executes a `getIamPolicy` and if the return is not what it expects it tries to recreate the wider permissions. So there is no way to fix this.

content.title: GPII-2951: DNS Route53 with subdomain delegation to Google DNS
content.body:
Terraform code to create the DNS zone at Route 53 and delegate subdomain to Google DNS

**WARNING: Do not merge this PR yet**

Before merging this PR consider the comments at https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-2951
comments: LGTM
LGTM

Sorry this review took me so long!

This looks good. I like how your module-of-modules approach makes things very DRY.

Once you've had a chance to respond to my comments, let's talk about how to get this code running in CI.

Confusion about commits and how Github shows them aside, I think this looks pretty good. Thanks for all the little renames and such.

I think you can ship this code (it own't hurt anything since nothing calls it) and we can proceed to integrating it with rake (blocked on me doing something with GPII-2990) and adding it to CI (maybe you can start on GPII-2995 if you're blocked waiting for me).

Hmm, whatever you are doing with commits is making github confused. Your whole branch shows up at the bottom of this PR, below all my comments, but commits are from 27 days ago. This prevents me from seeing what commits I've already reviewed and which ones are new.

My only clue as to what has changed since my last review are the emails github sends when you push a commit. The SHAs mentioned in these emails don't exist in this PR.

Ok now I'm seeing that the Commits tab has better information, i.e. correct dates. But the SHAs are still all different. This might be enough information, but please evaluate how you manage commits to prevent this problem in the future. Thanks.
Please change to gcp_project (projects are a GCP concept, not a GKE concept).
Let's use us-central1 (cheaper, more AZs, more VM options).
How about zone_name instead of recordname?

How does /common get mounted into the exekube container?

Aha, I found your comment in https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-2974?focusedCommentId=32404&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-32404. As noted in the ticket, I'm moving the conversation over here, where those changes are consumed.

I think the exekube-y way to handle this is to have a docker-compose.yaml per "environment". Since common/live/prd will be its own environment, it gets its own docker-compose.yaml (i.e., make a copy of https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/master/gcp/docker-compose.yaml in common/ and add the pip and .aws changes to it). This is nice because it keeps common/ and gcp/ isolated from one another. Also, we keep the AWS-only changes isolated to the only place that uses them.

A downside is that it is more docker-compose.yamls to manage, a possibly non-trivial task given how quickly exekube changes. I think the benefits outweigh this downside, though I'm happy to re-evaluate if it turns out to be a big pain.

If you follow the exekube pattern, you can change paths inside the container from /common to /project. Then, the /common mount in docker-compose.yaml is no longer needed.
How about zone_name (or record_name) instead of recordname?
How about name_servers (or ns_records) instead of nsrecords?
How about gcp_zone_in_aws?

The dns zones described in GPII-2951 are not part of gcp/live/dev (or gcp/live/stg or gcp/live/prd). Instead, they are part of a new long-lived "environment". Let's call it common/live/prd.[1]

Hence, rather than adding this file to gcp/live, please create a similar set of directories in common/live and move this file to common/live/prd/infra/dns/terraform.tfvars.

[1] We'll probably want a non-production environment for testing changes, but given the singleton nature of these DNS records I think we start with prd and the real `aws.gpii.net` and `gcp.gpii.net` and work backwards into a special case for testing like `aws-stg.gpii.net` (which is different from `stg.aws.gpii.net`!)
How about aws-dns-zone instead of awsdnszone?
How about gcp-dns-zone instead of gcpdnszone?
How about aws-gcp-dns instead of aws-gcloud-dns?
I don't think this provider is used here.
I don't think this provider is used here.
I think this is unused except by the (unused) google provider. Remove?
I think this is unused except by the (unused) google provider. Remove?

Because you copied this file and modified in a single commit, I almost missed this change. Please make separate commits for "noisy" operations like copying a file from somewhere else and for changes made to the copied file. It makes it much easier for reviewers to see what's going on. Thanks.

content.title: GPII-3397- Enable log exclusion for the CouchDB HTTP checks
content.body:
The log severity configured in the CouchDB containers is `info`, and this causes that the CouchDB logs every request from the health checks:
```
[notice] 2018-10-11T18:11:14.179590Z couchdb@couchdb-couchdb-1.couchdb-couchdb.gpii.svc.cluster.local <0.17722.0> 66cbd57ff5 localhost:5984 127.0.0.1 a99c4851ccfb586fa58727bcbb869a30 GET /_up 200 ok 2
```
This PR decreases the log level to `warn`.
http://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/config/logging.html#log/level
which is less noisy.
comments: Looks good. Personally I would decrease the log level and test if we can increase it without disrupting ops should we need to debug something.
The logs that spam the stackdriver has the level of [notice], `warn` is the immediate next level.
Having full request logs for DB layer is essential for audit purposes. I think we should keep current log level, and if those health checks are really noisy, configure exclusion instead.

I don't think it's correct to change the log level *or* to exclude this log message. My understanding is the cause of this message is a misconfigured liveness check. If so, I'd say the solution is to fix the liveness check. Silencing a log that revealed a real error seems counterproductive. Am I missing anything?

Let me summarize what we have.

If you go to your own dev cluster, at the log viewer and enter this filter (change your user in the project name):
```
resource.labels.cluster_name="k8s-cluster"
logName="projects/gpii-gcp-dev-<your_user>/logs/stderr"
resource.labels.container_name="couchdb"
```
you will see a lot of messages like this:
```
{
 insertId: "10crbmbg3hsmbrg"  
 logName: "projects/gpii-gcp-dev-alfredo/logs/stderr"  
 metadata: {…}  
 receiveTimestamp: "2018-10-16T17:51:51.412688468Z"  
 resource: {…}  
 severity: "ERROR"  
 textPayload: "[notice] 2018-10-16T17:51:47.560829Z couchdb@couchdb-couchdb-0.couchdb-couchdb.gpii.svc.cluster.local <0.31436.2> a0b399088c localhost:5984 127.0.0.1 629a540acb21d93a0f242baf2498b5d9 GET /_up 200 ok 2
"  
 timestamp: "2018-10-16T17:51:47Z"  
}
```
It you see at the end of the payload, it is a common request that returns a 200. It's an OK for the liveness and the readyness.

The problem here, IMHO, is that the CouchDB logs [every request to stderr](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/config/logging.html#log/writer) and the [Stackdriver understands that the severity is "ERROR"](https://cloud.google.com/kubernetes-engine/docs/how-to/logging#best_practices) for all the logs that the CouchDB throws, making very difficult to select only a type of log later on. So we have that all the logs of the CouchDB are marked as ERROR from the same source, without any other tags that help us to discriminate between a "real error" and a "200 request".

I feel that I'm out of ideas. These are my proposes:
1. Leave as it is now. We will have a lot of 200 messages, but we would also collect the real errors.
1. Increase the [severity of the logs in the CouchDB](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/config/logging.html#log/level). We will get rid of the `200 ok` logs and we would collect only other kind of messages.
1. Set an exclusion in Stackdriver. But since we don't have more fields to discriminate from one type of errors from others this could be hard to find out. The most accurate filter that I tried is:
```
resource.labels.cluster_name="k8s-cluster"
logName="projects/gpii-gcp-dev-<your_user>/logs/stderr"
resource.labels.container_name="couchdb"
```

> The problem here, IMHO, is that the CouchDB logs every request to stderr

@amatas I think this can be solved by configuring CouchDB to write logs into file:
http://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/config/logging.html#log/writer
And then using sidecar container to stream them, similarly to this example:
https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/logging/#streaming-sidecar-container

Probably worth trying. It would've been nice if we can have CouchDB logs with adequate severity. Not sure if it is required to configure health check requests exclusion though. This filter works for me (I know exact matches are faster, but since we don't have this option in our case):
```
resource.type="k8s_container"
resource.labels.container_name="couchdb"
textPayload : "GET / 200 ok 2"
```

@stepanstipl 
Ah, I mistook the log message in this PR for the log message in the associated ticket -- the subtly but significantly different `undefined GET / 200 ok 1`.

@amatas 
Thank you for the summary and explanation. I agree with @natarajaya that it seems the root cause is the disagreement between CouchDB and Stackdriver about what it means to write a message to stderr. However, I think a solution involving a sidecar is not worth the effort at this time.

An exclusion is cheap and addresses my main concern (keeping clutter out of the logs to make debugging easier) and my secondary concern (minimizing the amount and therefore cost of the logs we archive). I think an exclusion is the right move.

Sergey's filter looks good. I would add a space before `GET` because I'm always paranoid about false positives.

One thing that is unfortunate about this solution is the high coupling / low cohesion between this filter and the liveness check in the couchdb chart (especially with a lack of automated testing to tell us when we've changed one without changing the other). I can think of some solutions (make liveness check URL a rake variable and pass it to various terraform modules; couchdb module includes its own instance of gcp-stackdriver-exclude to manage this exclusion) but I don't think any of them are worth the trouble now.

@amatas thanks for the explanation. Can't we make CouchDB write logs to stdout? Otherwise this will be an issue with every single event - everything will be logged  with `severity: "ERROR"`, right?

I would prefer to fix this at the source (as opposed to fixing by exclusion). Also this will be an issue with log exports, the exclusions do not apply there, right?

> @amatas thanks for the explanation. Can't we make CouchDB write logs to stdout? Otherwise this will be an issue with every single event - everything will be logged with `severity: "ERROR"`, right?

I guess that we will have the same amount of logs but with the severity field with other value. That wouldn't decrease the amount of logs received.

> I would prefer to fix this at the source (as opposed to fixing by exclusion). Also this will be an issue with log exports, the exclusions do not apply there, right?

I agree with you @stepanstipl , but the CouchDB doesn't allow to set which logs goes to what severity. Perhaps putting an application in the middle that digests the logs and send them properly to the stackdriver would help. But it also adds some complexity. As @mrtyler and @natarajaya said before, perhaps we can improve this in the future.
LGTM

LGTM!

Can you please update this PR's title so we know it is about logging exclusions and not severity?

@stepanstipl @amatas I created separate ticket for CouchDB log severity issue:
https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3463
Does this mean that we're not going to see actual HTTP requests to CouchDB anymore in logs? If it is the case, I think this is undesirable.

I understand, by the documentation, that we would only remove the 2XX requests logs, other requests as 5XX will be logged. http://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/config/logging.html#log/level

Do you think that we should save ALL the HTTP requests? I think that those logs would demand more resources than the real value of that information.
Replied in PR thread.
It is readiness.

content.title: GPII-3125 Init GCP organization
content.body:
This code covers [GPII-3125](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3125), [GPII-3127](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3127), [GPII-3126](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3126) and [GPII-3128](https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3128).

More info about how to apply this code is in the [README.md](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/35b4ba9f9657b0c25e23c0f0d488d386453c7dd6/common/README.md)

This pr includes the following changes:

- Move the rakefiles to a common part shared by all the project types
- Create the DNS structure for a complete organization, in AWS and GCP
- The organization details are parametrized.
- Make idempotent the creation of the initial resources used by each environment
- Move some rake tasks to the Docker container
- `rake sh` gives a shell inside the container without making changes.

This is the plan to merge this PR:

1. Merge the PR :)
1. Let the CI test all until `stg`. This should create the initial resources for test1.gpii.net and create/destroy a complete dev testing cluster.
1. Manually import in the `prd` state file the projects already created in the organization in order to avoid naming conflicts and/or increase the projects quota.
1. Import the DNS zones that match the [DNS pattern](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/d60a61a5ee8d03cd11fb205cfceedbba817f5945/shared/rakefiles/vars.rb#L28-L36), delete others.
1. Promote to `prd` to recreate all the initial resources, DNS zones left, ns registries, SA of each project, activate API services and update the TF state of the common part.
1. Each individual project should refresh the TF state simply running `rake`, the CI will do automatically.
1. Re-run the complete pipeline in order to check that the idempotency works as expected.
comments:
This looks pretty good, Alfredo! I still think the strategy is sound. Most of my feedback is naming and organization changes that I hope will help with readability.

I haven't tried to run this code yet. Perhaps we should sit down together and go through it, make sure it works on my machine, make sure things that require Organization admin are idempotent, etc.

Lookin' good. I suggested a couple more small things (mostly deleting code :)).

Thank you for using merge instead of rebase so that I can keep track of what I've already reviewed. I'm fine with Stepan's suggestion of using rebase to clean up the history before merging to master.

I think the rest of your plan looks good. I'm fine with punting the stuff you punted.

Thanks for helping to test this code, Stepan!

The bug fixes generally look good.

I like the parameterization and the ability to do testing!

It looks like this branch does not contain my latest changes for `@serviceaccount_key_file` management. You're probably already aware and have a plan for this :).
Reminder that there are a few comments from my last review (8 days ago) that remain unresolved.
Some minor changes.

This review contains some more significant changes.

In particular, I have questions about the CI strategy.

1. Spinning up and then destroying a GCP dev cluster twice -- once as part of `gcp-dev`, once as part of `common-stg` -- is expensive and slow. As currently implemented, `common-stg` must complete successfully before `aws-stg` and `gcp-stg` can run.

2. There's a strange cycle where:
* Developer changes the way `common-prd` deploys dev environments.
* Developer merges their changes, triggering a CI pipeline.
* `gcp-dev` runs, but `common-prd` changes haven't been deployed yet.
* Later, `common-prd` runs, deploying the developer's changes.
* In the *next* pipeline (perhaps as much as a day later), `gcp-dev` finally runs in a world where the developer's changes have been deployed.

Maybe the pipeline should have a different order?
* setup
* unit-test
* common-stg
* common-promote-to-prd [1]
* common-prd
* dev [2]
* promote-to-stg
* stg
* promote-to-prd
* prd

[1] It's awkward to have a manual step early in the pipeline. Are we confident promoting common to prd automatically if common-stg succeeds?

[2] The dev Stage, and all subsequent Stages, include `aws-` and `gcp-` Jobs.

I'd like to discuss before we merge this PR.

I'm wondering if this is not an overly complicated way to achieve what we want. I don't think it's a problem of this PR as such, but rather of the whole repo structure. I know some of this is enforced given the used tooling, but that would be imho another reason to consider a simpler approach.

My main concerns being:
- **Many dependencies**, currently these are required (not limited to):
  - Ruby 
  - Rake - using Rakefiles
  - Terraform
  - Terragrunt
  - Custom fork of Exekube
  - Docker-compose
  - Docker (of course :))
  - Python (called from Tf)
  - gcloud cli
 
- **Complicated and confusing dir structure** - `common/live/prd/infra/development/` for example, each of these containing a significant amount of duplicated code (abusing DRY)

I think the complexity of this will backfire in future. In general, I'm a fan of Occam's razor principle & keep it simple.

As an alternative I would propose using pure Terraform with a Makefile, all packaged in Docker container, gcloud would still have to be there. I think the code for our purpose could then simply look something like:

```tf
...
module "dev-tyler" {
  source  = "modules/gcp-project"

  name    = "dev-tyler"
  owner   = "tyler@raisingthefloor.org"
}

module "dev-stepan" {
  source  = "module/gcp-project"

  name    = "dev-stepan"
  owner   = "stepan@raisingthefloor.org"
}
...
```

This would make this piece of code more maintainable with fewer dependencies.

We can also create the DNS zone per project here together with corresponding DNS records. For example the subdomains for the above code would be `.dev-tyler.gcp.gpii.net` and `.dev-stepan.gcp.gpii.net` and then the code for actual K8s infrastructure could create any records underneath.

(Probably, at least initially, I would also suggest leaving out the AWS DNS zone mgmt., and simply create one subdomain that would be "manually" delegated to GCP, as I assume we will want to get rid of AWS in future.)

@amatas I know it took me so long to review this! My overall impression is good, I replied on some comments in discussions started by Tyler. I did not go into Ruby code yet.

Main of my points here:
* Shared rakefiles / docker-compose configs
* Live directory structure (https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60#discussion_r205665333)
* Use Terraform native functions instead of Python (https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60#discussion_r205667215)
* How to re-use dns zone created in dev project (https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/files#r205671169)
 
Another question – how are we going to test this if we can not delete our existing projects and let this code recreate everything from scratch? :)

@stepanstipl:

> DNS - do we need different DNS structure for the dev projects?

One motivation for creating a dedicated `dev` zone was indeed to be able to give it different permissions (e.g. allowing subzones to be managed by non-admin users) from the `stg` and `prd` zones. This is needed under the current AWS model, but not under the current GCP model.

Another advantage of a dedicated `dev` zone is that it allows use of a wildcard SSL certificate (other than `*.gpii.net`). This might have been nice for using Amazon Certificate Manager with dev clusters. It may still be nice if/when we get to TLS encryption for internal network communications.

However, I don't know if these factors warrant the extra handling needed to distinguish between "tyler.dev.gpii.net" and "prd.gpii.net" -- it's certainly a question worth asking. What does the team think?

Note for @amatas (and @mrtyler ;)): I have replied to all the comments that I had replies for. I'm waiting to review code until things settle down a bit (otherwise it's hard for me to keep track of what has/hasn't been addressed). Please add a comment when you've taken at least a first pass at everything.

OK team, I think that this is ready for a second round of review if you all believe that it's needed. @natarajaya @mrtyler @seg10 @stepanstipl , thanks for your thoughts and code suggestions, feel also free to review the code and add any comments.

I've applied and tested almost all the corrections suggested. I've tested parts of the code using my personal account, but it was not possible for me to test all together due to the dependency of cloud providers and accounts involved.

The split or the reorganization of the rake files I think that could be addressed in a separate ticket, as is not critical for this work and I wouldn't like to grow the size of this PR. The same to the READMEs organization.

This time I have used the merge instead of rebasing the code. I read that using this method the history of the changes makes sense as you can see the original code that a commit patches, meanwhile using the rebase method you lost that original code. Also it seems that Github manages better the comments in the code of the PR.

@stepanstipl @mrtyler I'd vote for using what we have now, developers domains hanging from a `dev` zone. I think that is an advantage the dedicated permissions of that non critical zone. But as always, we can see how it goes. I think that a swap to the other model is not so difficult.

@stepanstipl This PR doesn't address the deleting of the projects. This is a good feature for a new task (which I'll create as well as others commented in this PR), but as I said before I'd like to merge this code by now and stop adding features to this PR.

My plan for applying this code in the running environments is this:

1. Merge the gcp/rakefiles/entrypoint.rake as it is the only file that has conflicts with the actual master.
1. Merge the PR
1. Checkout the code in a live session with other team members.
1. Import the resources that are already created in GCP and match the patterns used in this code:
   1. Projects
   1. Service accounts
   1. User accounts permissions
   1. Buckets
   1. DNS zones
   1. DNS registries
1. Check the `plan` output and see that it doesn't break or delete current resources.
1. Run `rake infra_init`
1. Check the resources updated and created
1. Run `rake project_init`
1. Run `rake apply_projects`
1. Check the resources created, paying attention to the DNS zones structure and the NS registries.

thanks @amatas 

- I like to merge while you're discussing the issues & do final rebase & squash to sensible commit chunks once approved and before you actually merge to master. Reason being, as you pointed out, keeping a history of changes and comments while working on the issue, but at the same time prevent all the "wip" commits getting into master.

- Importing resources already created - are we planning to import manually? That sounds like quite a tedious and error-prone process. Or is there s code to do this? Or re-use/merge current state file?
@mrtyler I added some commits to address your suggestions. Please check that everything is fine.

LGTM!

Let's talk tomorrow about how to deploy this branch!

Rake will fail with following error when running `rake auth`:
```
rake aborted!
Errno::ENOENT: No such file or directory @ rb_sysopen - ../../.config/prd/compose.env
```

Steps to reproduce:

- Follow `common/README.md` steps "Creating the initial infrastructure"

Looks like readme is referring to `../aws#configure-cloud-provider-credentials` for AWS creds setup, and that mentions 2 options - `aws configure` or manually putting creds in `~/.aws`. Exekube, on the other hand, seems to expect credentials in `./.config/${ENV}/aws`, which is used as docker-compose mount `/root/.aws`. thanks @stepanstipl I fixed both issues in https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/f7c2d222ecdf13acf37c4e304d38f02bc74a4aff and https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/514e66525c0d271cb46d233d369c3c7b8148fe43
@amatas is there a way to test the AWS DNS part? The zone `Z26C1YEN96KOGI` seems to be hardcoded.

`project_init` rake task fails with insufficient permissions:

```
module.gcp_zone.google_dns_managed_zone.main: Creating...
  description:    "" => "gcp DNS zone"
  dns_name:       "" => "gcp.stgca02.stipl.net."
  name:           "" => "gcp-gpii-net"
  name_servers.#: "" => "<computed>"
  project:        "" => "<computed>"
Releasing state lock. This may take a few moments...

Error: Error applying plan:

1 error(s) occurred:

* module.gcp_zone.google_dns_managed_zone.main: 1 error(s) occurred:

Terraform does not automatically rollback in the face of errors.
Instead, your Terraform state file has been partially updated with
any resources that successfully completed. Please address the error
above and apply again to incrementally change your infrastructure.
```
I assume it's because the `projectowner@gpii2-common-prd.iam.gserviceaccount.com` service account has only `Storage Admin` and `Viewer` permissions and therefore is unable to create the DNS zone.

Update: yes, adding `DNS Administrator` to the service account fixes the problem.

Terraform is checking and downloading provides every time it's being run:


This is slow and can mean a loss of consistent environment - if a new version is found, it will be downloaded.

We should
a) Specify versions of providers to lock these down
b) Predownload providers when we build the docker image and prevent any further downloads

I realised I'm not sure it's a good place for this, like in scope of this PR, maybe this should be separate issue?

Hi @stepanstipl ,

I think I've figured it out:

The first module `/project/live/prd/infra/dns-root` which is pointing to `/project/modules//aws-gcp-dns` and works fine has following provider declaration:
```
provider "google" {
  credentials = "${var.serviceaccount_key}"
  project     = "${var.project_id}"
  region      = "us-central1"
}
```

The second, failing one, `/project/live/prd/infra/prd/zone` which is pointing to `/project/modules//gcp-project` does not have any such provider declaration.

The first one, therefore, uses explicitly defined credentials, while the second one is trying to use default ones as described at https://www.terraform.io/docs/providers/google/index.html.
Good catch @stepanstipl ! I've added such provider to gcp-project module on https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/c09bd448064dbd92e010d46c300de270c4cdbdde

I would also prefer to have the other members parametrised (`group:ops@raisingthefloor.org`), instead of hardcoded in the module.

Atm. running `rake apply_project` always ends up in following error: 
```
[terragrunt] [/project/live/prd/infra/prd/zone] 2018/08/15 15:50:08 Running command: terraform apply -auto-approve -input=false -auto-approve
google_project.project: Refreshing state... (ID: gpii-gcp-prd2)

 connect: cannot assign requested address

exit status 1
```

I think these issues seem to be related to missing permissions.

One of the errors I get is:
```
* google_storage_bucket.project-tfstate: google_storage_bucket.project-tfstate: Error reading Storage Bucket "gpii-gcp-prd2-tfstate": googleapi: Error 403: projectowner@gpii-common-prd.iam.gserviceaccount.com does n
ot have storage.buckets.get access to gpii-gcp-prd2-tfstate., forbidden
```
The code is trying to access storage bucket of the individual project under the `projectowner@gpii-common-prd.iam.gserviceaccount.com` account but does not have permissions to do so. Adding smth like `Storage Admin` fixes the problem.

In general it might be good idea to add the permissions for the common account on Organization level, as they would get inherited?

Creating DNS zones fails with project named `prd2`. It's trying to create zone `prd.gcp.gpii.net.2` and that is not valid zone name. 

I guess the problem comes from the `/([a-z]+)-([a-z]+)-([a-z]+)-?([a-z]+)?/` regexp, which does not allow numbers in individual parts of the name.

```
google_dns_managed_zone.project: Creating...
  description:    "" => "gpii-gcp-prd2 DNS zone"
  dns_name:       "" => "prd.gcp.gpii.net.2"
  name:           "" => "gpii-gcp-prd2-zone"
  name_servers.#: "" => "<computed>"
  project:        "" => "gpii-gcp-prd2"
```

Hi @stepanstipl 

1. the projectowner should have owner permissions in each project: https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/65a8f02d1e2f6dc99c704c45271a988f4944a841/common/modules/gcp-project/main.tf#L64-L73
and also it has permissions on the common-prd project https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/65a8f02d1e2f6dc99c704c45271a988f4944a841/common/rakefiles/entrypoint-common.rake#L46-L48
I don't understand where it needs more privileges.
1. Changed the regular expression to allow digits in https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/65a8f02d1e2f6dc99c704c45271a988f4944a841

@amatas thanks, but looks like the last commit introduced an error:

```
[terragrunt] [/project/live/prd/infra/prd/zone] 2018/08/16 15:08:30 Running command: terraform apply -auto-approve -input=false -auto-approve

Error: Error parsing /root/.terragrunt/QwL5tE0zt_C6_1_1Ybv6FwtLII4/exDWDCWoRRnBaZ-HQfLUjTVcEno/gcp-project/main.tf: At 32:47: illegal char escape
```

Re. the storage permission - I think it's probably related to the previous one, when the service account name does not respect the project name - even if the main project is named `gpii2-common-prd`, as you can't have 2 projects with same names on GCP, the service account is still hadrcoded to  `projectowner@gpii-common-prd.iam.gserviceaccount.com`. So ignore that, it'll get fixed once the svc account name matches the project name.

The issue is when trying to set `ops@raisingthefloor.org` as `roles/owner` in IAM policy. Owner role can only be taken by service account or user (see https://cloud.google.com/resource-manager/reference/rest/v1/projects/setIamPolicy).

```
$ python -c 'print("{\"zone\": \"" + ".".join("gpii-gcp-dev-alfredo".split("-")[::-1]) + ".net." + "\"}")'
{"zone": "alfredo.dev.gcp.gpii.net."}
```

it takes the name of the project `gpii-gcp-dev-alfredo` and returns the DNS zone in json format: `{"zone": "alfredo.dev.gcp.gpii.net."}`

The command split the project name by the hyphens and rejoin them in the other way around ([::-1]), adds a .net at the end and wrap all in {"zone": "dnsname"}.
