How about using `-output=json` and parsing that instead of using a regular expression against a (possibly non-stable) text output format?
Why is this a separate stage, instead of being part of the `stg` stage?
Did you set up a specific builder for this tag?
Since you're doing this calculation in Ruby code as well as in several places in Terraform code, how about doing it once in `set_vars()` and referring to the result of that calculation where needed?
I find this name confusing since each gcp/live environment has its own `infra` directory. How about `refresh_common_infra`?
What does this mean? Can you remove one now?
This seems like a pain. Assuming we can't fix it now, can you create a ticket and reference that ticket from here?
I find this name confusing since each gcp/live environment has its own infra directory. How about `apply_common_infra`?

The name of the testing organization is "gpii2test" and the domain used for that organization is "test1.gpii.net". A sample of the name of the projects created is `gpii2test-gcp-dev-joe`, which doesn't match with the domain name.

In the case of the GPII projects, the project name includes the `gpii` string of the `gpii.net`, we assumed the `.net`. That's why I introduce the `organization_domain` in the code, because the name of the organization may not match the domain name, and we use the name of the organization to give a name for the projects.
Deleted, I used this function in the implementation of a solution that didn't work as expected.
Yes, I did
It is needed by the second part of the job, where a dev environment (dev-doe) is created in the testing organization using the `gcp` code.
And I only wanted to be sure that the common-stg is always applied in the testing organization.
I would use an obvious test value that could never be a default, such as `fake-org-domain`.

I don't understand this change.

I also think it's pretty unexpected to deploy an entire gcp/dev environment in the middle of a common/stg deployment. Why are we doing this? Is there a different approach we can take?

The goal of the `stg` environment of the common part is the testing of the initialization of the organization, and whether all the resources created are able to support the dev/stg/prd environments. I think that a dev environment is the worst case scenario where multiple subdomains (also set by the initial resources) are involved. That's why a dev environment of a virtual user is created. We can also add the creation of a stg or prd environment if needed.
And all of the above avoiding any interaction with the real production organization (*.gcp.gpii.net).
Done, I've used the output command that supports the json output.
I've deleted this line in favor of using TF_VAR_domain_name.
I deleted the unused variables.
Done.
Because it uses a set of ENV variables that is not needed in the stg stage.

Looks like it's trying to import every time. The condition should probably be smth like `if !id_found`

```
module.gke_network.google_dns_managed_zone.dns_zones: Importing from ID "joe-dev-gcp-test1-gpii-net"...
module.gke_network.google_dns_managed_zone.dns_zones: Import complete!
  Imported google_dns_managed_zone (ID: joe-dev-gcp-test1-gpii-net)

Error: module.gke_network.google_dns_managed_zone.dns_zones (import id: joe-dev-gcp-test1-gpii-net): Can't import module.gke_network.google_dns_managed_zone.dns_zones, would collide with an existing resource.

Please remove or rename this resource before continuing.
```
Ticket created: https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3332
Done on https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/35b4ba9f9657b0c25e23c0f0d488d386453c7dd6

I think the second one should be "gpii-common-stg".

I don't understand "if it's the case" and I would delete it.
I don't understand the comment at the end, and I would remove it.
I don't understand the comment at the end, and I would remove it.
Please re-add the trailing `\`.

I had to look up this `!!` convention. Might be worth a comment.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/524658/what-does-mean-in-ruby
I would rename `id_found` to `dns_zone_found`.

Env vars are set at the Job level, not the Stage level, so I'm not sure I understand your reply.

Unless I'm missing something -- or unless we change the Job order completely, I think you should:

1. Delete the Stages entries `common-stg` and `common-prd`.
2. Change the `common-stg` Job to be in Stage `stg`.
3. Change the `common-prd` Job to be in Stage `prd`.

I'm not sure if it's worth opening this can of worms but:

I wonder if it would make the code simpler If we changed the Project naming convention to "gpii-net-gcp-dev-tyler"?

In fact, I wonder if it would make the code simpler if we changed the Project naming convention to exactly mirror DNS naming, i.e. "tyler-dev-gcp-gpii-net"?

Maybe it's too late to propose these kinds of changes. On the other hand, this naming convention will be a lot harder to change once this PR is deployed.

This line won't be reached if there is a failure during `rake`, which will lead to a dev environment getting left behind. This seems like a significant problem to me. Do you agree? How should we proceed?

(Github won't let me add this comment where I want it.)

Should we have `common-promote-to-stg` and `common-promote-to-prd` Jobs?

(Github won't let me add this comment where I want it.)

At some point (maybe right now :)) it sounds like you'll want to enable the (currently disabled) `gcp-stg` and `gcp-prd` Jobs.
Looks like you didn't do this one. Why not?
`after_script` is maybe a step in the right direction. What will this do if there is a failure early in the `script` section and the dev environment is never created?

I have to review manually all the changes I make. I mean, unfold all the "hide outdated" to realize that everything is covered. You should expect that github leaves the unmodified code visible, but it's not the case many times. It auto refreshes the page when I make the push event and some comments goes to hidden. That's why I also missed other comments in the previous reviews.

@amatas Maybe I am missing something, but it is not clear to me why do we need another `shared` dir just for rake files? Our shared Helm charts live in `common/charts`, why don't have rake files in `common/rakefiles`?
@amatas We use underline `_` as "space substitution" for other rake files: `ci_save_all.rake`, `sh_filter.rb`. I would suggest to use the same style.

@amatas Why do we need these changes? `sh "#{@exekube_cmd} sh"` is not the same  as `sh "#{@exekube_cmd} rake xk['#{cmd}',skip_secret_mgmt]"`. With this, secrets will not be applied when you call `rake sh` without providing command, and shell output will not be obfuscated.
I am fine with any of those, but agree that if team decides to use "tyler-dev-gcp-gpii-net" naming convention, now is a good time for the change.
`unless` instead of `if not`, `then` is usually omitted in constructions like this in Ruby.

Maybe it looks more proper, but you don't really need this:
```
irb(main):001:0> require 'json'
=> true
irb(main):002:0> a = '{}'
=> "{}"
irb(main):003:0> a_found = JSON.parse(a)
=> {}
irb(main):004:0> puts 'Got ya!' if a_found
Got ya!
```

I don't think that `xk.rake` is a right place for `:refresh_common_infra` and `:apply_common_infra` tasks. It is intended to be a lightweight wrapper for commands that require secrets to be set prior to execution. Is there anything that prevents moving those 2 tasks to common entrypoint rake file? Maybe all the sh code should live in Terraform module? I can help if needed.

Beside the fact that we don't use [backtick calls ](http://ruby-doc.org/core-1.9.3/Kernel.html#method-i-60) in other rake files, why don't just:
```
sh "#{@exekube_cmd} sh -c ' \
  if [ \"$(gsutil ls -p #{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]} | grep tfstate)\" == \"\" ]; then \
    gsutil mb gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate \
  fi \
  gsutil versioning set on gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate \
'"
```

We need a separate directory outside the `common` and `gcp` directory where [these imports of the entrypoint.rake](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/d2a4efb99a5dd9c02806d3ac16f92ff7f43244be/shared/rakefiles/entrypoint.rake#L3-L4) could work in both cases because it uses the same relative path. If the rake files live in the `common` directory the import would be different if you call the rakes from `common` and `gcp`, so in one of the cases will fail.

I introduced this changes in order to avoid load functions if I only need a shell to debug inside the container. In which cases do we need to load the secrets when we invoke "rake sh"?

Before these changes, if I just wanted to test my TF code I had to authenticate against gcloud and do some stuff to get the SA, which in that time when I was debugging they didn't exist at GCP.
I know, but I like to use the proper variable type always I can.

Both tasks don't require secrets, they only need to be authenticated in GCP, that's why the `@gcp_creds_file` is a dependency.

Also they are invoked from [entrypoint.rake](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/d2a4efb99a5dd9c02806d3ac16f92ff7f43244be/shared/rakefiles/entrypoint.rake#L79) and [entrypoint_common.rake](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/blob/d2a4efb99a5dd9c02806d3ac16f92ff7f43244be/shared/rakefiles/entrypoint-common.rake#L10) by tasks that set the secrets.

But if secrets were needed, I'd vote for creating a new task inside xk.rake in order to manage them and then use it as a dependency by other tasks. I think that one goal is to have as much as possible inside the Docker container.

I can not see the advantages of adding an extra layer to the sh commands. I mean using `rake -> terraform -> sh` instead of `rake -> sh`.

I don't mind to use your suggested code, but I can not see a real advantage: relay on sh conditionals or ruby, save some chars vs more backslashes. Let the team vote: @stepanstipl @mrtyler @seg10 what do you think?

```
  `#{@exekube_cmd} gsutil ls gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate`
  if $?.exitstatus != 0
    sh "#{@exekube_cmd} gsutil mb gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate"
  end

  sh "#{@exekube_cmd} gsutil versioning set on gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate" 
```

or

```
sh "#{@exekube_cmd} sh -c ' \
  if [ \"$(gsutil ls -p #{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]} | grep tfstate)\" == \"\" ]; then \
    gsutil mb gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate \
  fi \
  gsutil versioning set on gs://#{ENV["TF_VAR_project_id"]}-tfstate \
'"
```
I think that you can also run `rake sh[bash]` to get the same behavior that the task has in master.
done
I don't like either very much :D, and in general I'm not big fan of backtick calls, but definitely the 1st example, with less escaping, is much more readable

@amatas If it is only about relative path for rake file imports, then this should do the trick:
```
@rakefiles_dir = File.dirname(__FILE__)

import "#{@rakefiles_dir}/ci.rake"
import "#{@rakefiles_dir}/test.rake"
```
I would be very happy if we get rid of additional `shared` dir and let our rake files live in `common`!

@amatas Ok, I understand this now. Example of situation when we need secrets inside exekube shell is [CouchDB data restoration](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/tree/master/gcp#restoring-couchdb-data). Different behaviors for `rake sh` that simply invokes bash and for `rake sh[bash]` that does the same but via ruby code in container, is a bit confusing. Maybe introduce something like `:plain_sh` for that purpose? But I am okay leaving this as it is for now.

This is fine. But again, if the choice is to use the code that works and easy to understand, or the code that requires you to lookup stackoverflow in order to understand whats happening, I would choose the first option :)

@amatas Ok, I am still convinced that those tasks belong to entrypoint and entrypoint_common. However, I understand if you don't want to deal with this now and want to focus on merging this PR instead. We can fix this later.
I would prefer to have secrets by default - you need these to be able to debug or work at all with TF state, without you can't do much (well anything with TF)
Same as in [previous thread](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60#discussion_r217216485). Let's merge this PR to get things rolling, and work on improving this later.

@natarajaya could we move forward this PR and tackle this in a separate ticket?. This change was discussed at the beginning with @mrtyler (https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/60/commits/69a69b2cdb7d6f2f34c0ee829ff28a767c07a873) , and we found the solution of using a shared directory for shared resources like helm charts and rakefiles that are not tied directly with a particular environment (common is an environment itself with a particular pipeline). I wouldn't like to revert this work now.

Seriously, if the agreement is to have the rakefiles inside `common` I will be fine with that. But please, let's merge this PR first and revert this change if so later.
I've leave the original task as `:rake_shell` and created a new one `:plain_shell` for covering those cases where someone wants to get into a shell without external dependencies
We aggreed to decline this change.

content.title: Deploy kube state metrics
content.body:
This PR deploys **kube state metrics** add-on to the clusters. This add-on expores additional Kubernetes cluster-level metrics to Stacdriver. Example of these metrics can be `kube_deployment_spec_replicas` or `kube_pod_status_ready`.

**Changelog:**
- Add kube-state-metrics chart
- Add kube-state-metrics TF module
- Deploy kube-state-metrics module across environments
- Update prometheus-to-sd-exporter to v0.9.2
- Add kube-state-metrics docker image to versions

**Testing:**
These changes have been tested in dev env, both updating existing and creating new cluster from scratch.

**Downtime:**
This is a no-downtime change, no impact on services is expected.

**_~Note: This is WIP~_**
There is couple of error messages from the prometheus-to-sd I want to look at prior to merging:
```
E0312 16:49:11.237915       1 stackdriver.go:97] Error in attempt to update metric descriptor googleapi: Error 400: Field labels had an invalid value: When creating metric custom.googleapis.com/kube-state-metrics/kube_pod_labels: the metric has more than 10 labels., badRequest
W0312 16:49:11.238549       1 translator.go:199] Metric process_start_time_seconds invalid or not defined. Using 1970-01-01 00:00:01 +0000 UTC instead. Cumulative metrics might be inaccurate.
```
^ the above was resolved by disabling the kube_pod_labels metric.
comments: LGTM, only one comment

Two thinks here related to the costs of having custom metrics:

- Are all of those needed? (I've read the line and I think so)
- Would it be better to have this in a variable? is it worth it?

> Are all of those needed?

It depends on what metrics are we interested in. I've reviewed the cons of SD metrics and it doesn't seem to be too high (at least compared to logging cost for example), and of course these will only be collected if there are corresponding resources to monitor.

I would leave all of these on initially (there are more, but some not compatible with older K8s API) and once we learn which are useful and which are not, we can reduce this list of collected resources. It's further possible to whitelist only specific namespaces.

> Would it be better to have this in a variable? is it worth it?

Sounds like a good idea, done in the latest commit.

content.title: GPII-3394: Add couchdb-prometheus-exporter
content.body:
This is an alternative approach for collecting metrics from CouchDB, suggested by @stepanstipl in https://github.com/gpii-ops/stackdriver-agent/pull/2. After some investigation and a demo today based on this PR, we decided to move forward with this solution.

Rendered README for new chart:
https://github.com/mrtyler/gpii-infra/tree/gpii-3394-cpe/shared/charts/couchdb-prometheus-exporter 

There is a commit where I only copied the gpii-preferences chart, in case you'd like to see those interdiffs. (I forgot to do the same for the gcp/modules entry and the live/dev entries; sorry.)
comments:
Looks good in general.

I would like to understand a bit more about `couchdb-prometheus-exporter` HA mode, what is the reason for multiple replicas and what is the relationship to the number of nodes of the CouchDB cluster. Can you please elaborate a bit on that?

Some minor things, looks good! Thanks for the changes!

> Anyway, I would like to move on from this problem. I don't think the unwanted stats are a big deal for now, and our longer-term metrics collection future is somewhat uncertain. Pending new feedback, I think this PR is ready to merge.

I don't think this is a problem - in general, I'm more in favor keeping more metrics than less (of course within reason), as you never know what you might need in the future for debugging some specific problem. I would leave this atm. as it is.

> Do you have an alternative solution for HA that avoids these issues?

I don't. I would probably go with just instance of exporter and relly on Kubernetes as HA mechanism and that it should restart the exporter if anything bad happens. I think it's a bit confusing if you have to think about de-duping in all your queries, how would you build alert policies? (hard-coding node name sound less than optimal, as this can change over the time... just think about node upgrade). So I would expect monitoring to be de-duped before it hist your storage system, but probably not a big deal.
LGTM

Ok, I believe I have addressed all the feedback and incorporated everything from our discussion today about cpu/memory requests/limits.

The last piece was looking into filtering the unwanted `go_*` and `process_*` metrics output by the metrics exporter. prometheus-to-sd does not have a denylist. It does have an allowlist ("whitelist") but I couldn't make it work (these logs are with `--v=9` i.e. the noisiest log level):

```
I1213 02:07:52.571009       1 translator.go:134] Exporting only whitelisted metrics: [couchdb_httpd_up couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses couchdb/httpd_up couchdb/httpd_auth_cache_misses custom/couchdb/httpd_up custom/couchdb/httpd_auth_cache_misses]
I1213 02:07:52.571025       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric couchdb_httpd_up not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571030       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571034       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric couchdb/httpd_up not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571038       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric couchdb/httpd_auth_cache_misses not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571042       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric custom/couchdb/httpd_up not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571047       1 translator.go:140] Whitelisted metric custom/couchdb/httpd_auth_cache_misses not present in Prometheus endpoint.
I1213 02:07:52.571055       1 stackdriver.go:38] No metrics to send to Stackdriver for component couchdb
```

Here's some output from the exporter:

```
$ cat couchdb-prometheus-exporter.metrics.txt | grep httpd_up
# HELP couchdb_httpd_up Was the last query of CouchDB stats successful.
# TYPE couchdb_httpd_up gauge
couchdb_httpd_up 1

$ cat couchdb-prometheus-exporter.metrics.txt | grep auth_cache_miss
# HELP couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses number of authentication cache misses
# TYPE couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses gauge
couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses{node_name="couchdb@couchdb-couchdb-0.couchdb-couchdb.gpii.svc.cluster.local"} 134855
couchdb_httpd_auth_cache_misses{node_name="couchdb@couchdb-couchdb-1.couchdb-couchdb.gpii.svc.cluster.local"} 11429
```

I'm not sure why the names don't match. The next step would be to add debugging to prometheus-to-sd to see what it wants. However, I think this approach would force us to maintain a list of stats we want, which is undesirable.

Another approach would be to fork couchdb-prometheus-exporter and remove the unwanted stats. This may require some effort, as I think the `go_*` and `process_*` stats are coming from the Prometheus exporter framework somewhere.

Anyway, I would like to move on from this problem. I don't think the unwanted stats are a big deal for now, and our longer-term metrics collection future is somewhat uncertain. Pending new feedback, I think this PR is ready to merge.
@mrtyler why force-push? I can't use "see changes since last review" functionality 👎

> why force-push? I can't use "see changes since last review" functionality

I force-pushed to make some trivial fixes in a couple commits (e.g. README formatting). I only force-pushed to new commits at the tip of the branch, never changing order or removing commits, so it is possible to reconstruct the "since last review" using the "Changes from all commits" dropdown. But that's annoying; I didn't realize Github wouldn't handle this situation. Sorry for the confusion.

> I'm more in favor keeping more metrics than less (of course within reason), as you never know what you might need in the future for debugging some specific problem.

I agree with this sentiment. In this specific case, the stats I'd like to exclude are stats about the exporter itself -- the thing that curls a couchdb endpoint, turns the resulting json into prometheus metrics format, and returns the massaged data when curl'd. I hope we never encounter a problem where six weeks of garbage collection data from this component is the key to the solution :).

> I would probably go with just instance of exporter and relly on Kubernetes as HA mechanism and that it should restart the exporter if anything bad happens.

Counterpoint: running one instance guarantees we lose metrics on node upgrades and reboots, and on Pod re-deploys (though this is generally a smaller window). However, your arguments about de-duping are compelling so I now think starting with one instance and seeing how it does is the simplest thing.
LGTM
👍 looks good, thanks for addressing all the bits!

I would prefer limits and requests to be the same, otherwise, you can hit unpredictable behavior when sometimes there are extra cpu resources available and sometimes not. Given this should be an essential part of the cluster, I would increase the `requests_cpu` to `50m` too (or whatevr the appropriate value is, but align `requests` and `limits` to the same one).
Same as above.
On what basis is `128Mi` chosen? Just that it seems like relatively a lot for a `go` app.
On what basis is `128Mi` chosen? Just that it seems like relatively a lot for a `go` app.
Why 2 replicas? Is this supposed to match a number of CouchDB pods? Or does it have some leader election mechanism? I'm not familiar with how this works, can you please explain?
Same as above. Also, I quite dislike repeating the whole requests/limits block, can we set some sensible defaults and overwrite only if needed for a given environment?
As mentioned above, I would set some sensible defaults here to avoid repeating this for each env.
I know it's in the chart yaml, but can we add the link to the actual GitHub repo (https://github.com/gesellix/couchdb-prometheus-exporter) somewhere in the Readme as well?
Is this some default CouchDB password? I think settings here should reflect whatever is the default for CouchDB

I remember this conversation from a different PR, but I thought we must have settled on the current scheme (memory the same, allow cpu to burst) because I copied these values from gpii-preferences.

I added a Parking Lot item to discuss this more broadly. Then, I'm happy to fix this everywhere in a follow-up PR (I noticed another small thing in gpii-preferences that I'd like to fix anyway).

I hid this in the commit message:

"Observed memory usage at idle and under small and moderate loads -- steady around
40MB. Tripled that for safety and rounded to 128Mi.

Observed CPU usage at idle and under small and moderate loads -- steady around 0.00 :). Rounded up to 25m for safety."

Maybe 60 or 80 is a better value? I couldn't find a good rule of thumb for this in sixty seconds of searching. I added a Parking Lot item for this discussion as well.
As above.

I was thinking of [Prometheus's "High Availability" strategy](https://prometheus.io/docs/introduction/faq/#can-prometheus-be-made-highly-available):  scrape it N times and let someone downstream de-dupe it.

The incoming metrics are tagged with the Node running the metrics exporter. I think that should be sufficient if we need to de-dupe or otherwise distinguish which exporter produced a specific metric. (I think I will add some scheduling hints to prevent two exporter Pods from running on the same Node.)

The advantage of this system is simplicity: we won't lose all metrics collection during Pod or Node restarts, but the exporters don't have to know anything about one another or coordinate in any way.

I think we had a problem to figure the "working" values out. I still believe having same "requests" and "limits" for these types of workloads is a way to get more predictable behavior, but happy to discuss at standup.

It seems to me like `3x` is very generous buffer, perhaps smth. like `1.5x` would be enough, but I don't have a good answer. What I do usually is to have a look at what the program is actually consuming and if appropriate try to put it under load to see if/how it increases and then add some small buffer on top of that.

Where will the de-duping happen?

Won't we see all the metrics twice in Stackdriver? This sounds a bit in opposition with the concern of not shipping all/too many things to Stackdriver (as we have to pay for that). I would personally wonder if it won't be too confusing seeing all the metrics 2x (if that's the case).

Otherwise, 👍 for thinking about HA, I agree that from that point of view this seems simple & good. Just need to make the de-duping happen somewhere imho.

> This sounds a bit in opposition with the concern of not shipping all/too many things to Stackdriver (as we have to pay for that).

I don't mind paying for HA. What I don't like is paying for metrics we will definitely never use.

>  I would personally wonder if it won't be too confusing seeing all the metrics 2x (if that's the case).

In my limited experience with Stackdriver Metrics Explorer and Dashboard so far, I have not found it confusing. The incoming metrics are tagged with the Node running the metrics exporter. I think that should be sufficient if we need to de-dupe or otherwise distinguish which exporter produced a specific metric.

Do you have an alternative solution for HA that avoids these issues?
This was all copied from gpii-preferences. I agree with your suggestion and I'm moving the defaults into the chart level.
Good suggestion.
Good suggestion.
I settled on 80Mi, or ~2x observed memory usage.
This is already a default value, why repeat?
Just cosmetic, but maybe no blank line here?
hm, why do we use `camelCase` here  vs `under_score` naming convention for other variables?
Reading further, I noticed it's not a default in the `gcp/modules/couchdb-prometheus-exporter` module, maybe make it default there as well to avoid repetition in envs?
I think this would be good to parametrize, especially the image version. Sorry I didn't notice before.
Conversation continues [below](https://github.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/pull/230#pullrequestreview-184729878).
`terraform fmt` put it there. 🤷‍♀️
I'll look at this in the follow-up cleanup PR. Looks like camel case is the convention for Charts.
Done.
Done.
:D ok then I guess

content.title: [GPII-2782] - 1 - High-Level Task: Secure Backups
content.body:
This is the first PR of the implementation of exporting backups task. This PR cover this 3 parts:

1. Backup exporter Service account and de permissions needed at the common level to allow cloudbuild to perform the operations. (The command `gcloud compute image export` creates a Cloudbuild job that makes all the work using a VM)
1. Backup exporter Helm Chart
1. Backup exporter GCP module.

This PR only affects to the common part as it will enable the APIs involved and create the backup-exporter service account. This PR can be promoted safely to prd.

If the common part is merge it will help me with the implementation of the rest of the task, because I wouldn't need to redeploy my cluster every time that the pipeline is executed.

This is the Terragrunt definition I'm using for testing, just in case someone wants to give a try:
```
# gcp/live/dev/k8s/kube-system/backup-exporter/terraform.tfvars 
# ↓ Module metadata

terragrunt = {
  terraform {
    source = "/project/modules//backup-exporter"
  }

  dependencies {
    paths = [
      "../k8s-snapshots",
    ]
  }

  include = {
    path = "${find_in_parent_folders()}"
  }
}

# ↓ Module configuration (empty means all default)

destination_bucket = "gs://gpii-backup-dev-alfredo"
replica_count      = 2
schedule           = "*/10 * * * *"
```
Tasks left for the next PRs:
- A way to create the destination bucket. A little bit tricky, because I need to give permissions (first part of the pipeline) to this bucket and I need the SA created first (which is created in later steps).
- Add the module in the Terragrunt definition of prd (is it needed in stg and dev clusters?)
- Document how to restore the cluster using the exported snapshots
- Alert when a backup fails

Thanks for sharing this early in the process. I have some high-level questions.

0. You may have said this once during standup but: have you successfully restored from a backup created using this strategy?

1. How often will the backup task run? How often does the Instance get created and destroyed?

2. How will we expire backups?

3. Why is ssh access needed? Maybe temporary for development/debugging?

4. Brendan's original specification calls for "cross-account, cross-region". That's sort of AWS specific, but I think the idea is to both improve resilience (cross-region in case one region goes down) and to make it harder for automation or human error to delete or modify the backups (cross-account so that "delete all the Snapshots" cannot delete both the primary Snapshots and the backups). Maybe storing the backups in a GCS bucket (or whatever) in a different Project is the appropriate metaphor for GCP?

What does the team think of this requirement?

Thanks Alfredo for this. I'll not go into details of this solution at this stage, but I'm a bit concerned about the overall approach. I'm thinking that spinning up a VM to do this, mounting disks etc.... might be unnecessary and opens a lot of questions, not only about security and data encryption.

What if we can do this VMless? And using `gcloud` native tools?

I would consider following:
- Export the disk images to GCS Bucket, this would involve:
  - `gcloud compute images create` which creates an image from a persistent disk or a snapshot
  -  `gcloud compute images export` which exports an image to GCS Bucket (see https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/images/export-image for details)
(if we want to use TF, I would check - it might have corresponding resources).

At this stage, we have backups in GCS and we can do pretty much anything we want with those. If this would stay within GCP, I would use `gsutil cp` that can copy data between buckets, even across different projects, without actually ever downloading them. `gsutil` seems to be even able to handle transfers from GCS to S3 (although in this case the data are pushed through the machine running the command).

I think all this can be run either on Kubernetes (maybe `CronJob`), or maybe even better as part of some CI build (perhaps CloudBuild?). In general, I would a) try to avoid pulling data to the client machine if possible (ie. do direct transfers between buckets) b) if not leverage fast connectivity inside the cloud (ie. don't run this on Gitlab if we have to pull data)

And I would try to avoid having to spin-up, manage and monitor new infrastructure, unless really necessary.

I believe this would allow us to simplify things a lot, leverage GCP data encryption and authz/n mechanisms, speed up and be less error-prone and easier to maintain.

> What does the team think of this requirement?

I would probably relax this to use GCS under different Project, and maybe Organization even. I would use perhaps multi-regional buckets, and Nearline/Coldline to reduce costs. And I would use GCS native Lifecycle Mgmt. to manage downgrade of the storage classes and deletion of objects (see. https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/lifecycle).

Cool Alfredo, I like this way more 👍 seems pretty neat.

> it's the number of couchdb replicas, which should be the same as the number of snapshots made at the same time.

Ok, looking at this again based on your previous answer I see one issue:

```
SNAPSHOTS=$(gcloud compute snapshots list --sort-by=~creationTimestamp,STATUS --limit={{ .Values.replicaCount }} --format="value[separator=';'](name,status)" | cut -f1 -d\;)
```

If the `replicaCount` is used to match number of replicas, we're not guaranteed to get consistent backup. Due to how snapshots happen, they don't happend atomically from all the instances at the same time. So imagine state of snapshots being smth like this (ordered by timestamp desc):

```
ReplicaA - 4pm snapshot
ReplicaB - 3pm snapshot
ReplicaA - 3pm snapshot
```

Above code with the `replicaCount` of two would backup snapshot from 4pm from replicaA and snapshot from 3pm from replicaB.

Or even worse, imagine:
```
ReplicaA - 4pm snapshot
ReplicaA - 3pm snapshot
ReplicaB - 3pm snapshot
```

The code would back up two snapshots from replica A, but not from replica B.

I'm not sure if the first example is an issue, but the second I think definitely is.

Maybe we can leverage predictable replicas/snapshot naming to always select the latest snapshot of each replica?

content.title: GPII-2960: Fix for couchdb module to execute finish_cluster action after chart install
content.body: We are also missing persistent volumes, will create separate PR for that.
comments:
This looks pretty good. I'm pleased to see that you're doing the work at the exekube level, as close as possible to the problem.

Is there a way to do all this directly with helm? That might be better -- helm is even closer to the problem than the exekube/terraform code -- but I'm not sure helm can handle this kind of thing.

My biggest question is around scaling the couchdb cluster dynamically. One of the main advantages of the (admittedly more complex) couchdiscover-based solution is that it could handle adding a new node to  the cluster dynamically. It doesn't look to me like this code could handle that scenario. Maybe @amatas has more thoughts on this.

IIRC, couchdiscover can handle scaling **up** but not scaling **down**. (@amatas is my recollection correct?) If so, this is something to consider while comparing the two strategies.

Re: timeouts: That's a bummer. And just to confirm, generic Terraform timeouts don't work? https://www.terraform.io/docs/configuration/resources.html#timeouts

Re: assigning Pods to Nodes: my experience so far has been that Kubernetes is smart about spreading Pods amongst Nodes / amongst AZs. Maybe it will be different when we have more Nodes and/or more couchdb Pods than AZs.

couchdiscover, add the nodes to the cluster and also "finishes" the couchdb cluster. Also it rebalances all the data along the nodes when a new node joins to the cluster. It also sets the Erlang cookie needed to the internal communication of the cluster.

https://github.com/amatas/couchdiscover/blob/master/couchdiscover/couch.py#L469-L497

The [Couchdb Statefulset Assembler](https://github.com/kocolosk/couchdb-statefulset-assembler) seems to don't do the above. It only "add" the nodes to the cluster, it doesn't finish the cluster and neither rebalance the shards. It seems to me that it doesn't complete the [steps to create a cluster](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/latest/cluster/setup.html#the-cluster-setup-api). But perhaps this is not needed anymore with the latest version of the CouchDB Docker container.

I'd do the following test:

1. Create a cluster of at least 3 nodes.
1. Load data into it, if it's possible while some of the node containers are in the "starting" state and the cluster is not finished. (The dataloader can start sending the data even if the cluster is not finished)
1. Remove (or kill) random nodes and try to retrieve the same data from the rest of alive nodes.

The scaling down using couchdiscover is not covered. If a node vanishes it won't be used until the next time that comes alive (the data, and the config is stored in the PV), the data will be also propagated and it will become online after that. The cluster reliability won't be affected while all the data is spread along the live nodes.

@amatas @mrtyler Current `couchdb` Helm chart installs CouchDB 2.1.1 (latest) and uses [CouchDB StatefulSet Assembler](https://github.com/kocolosk/couchdb-statefulset-assembler/blob/master/mem3_helper.py) as sidecar.

I performed a number of tests and found the following:
- Immediately after pods become "Running" cluster enters `cluster_enabled` [state](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/2.1.0/api/server/common.html#cluster-setup). Which means that nodes are already in cluster and only system databases are missing.
- If I keep cluster in this state and let `gpii-dataloder` to do its job, all docs of `gpii` database would be available from any of 2 nodes of the cluster.
- It scales cluster up pretty well, new nodes appear as `cluster_nodes` in the output of [_membership](http://docs.couchdb.org/en/2.1.0/api/server/common.html#membership) query. All docs of `gpii` database become available from any node of the cluster after scaling. It does NOT rebalance shards (so it probably makes sense to have one replica of stateful set per node?).
- Scaling cluster down not covered.

So looks like the only differences between `couchdiscover` solution is that `couchdisover` rebalances shards after scaling the cluster (though I was not able to find that functionality in their docs).

I could think of moving this fix from Terraform level to Helm level, as a Kubernetes `Job`. But there is no straightforward way to get statuses of other pods from inside of a pod, to determine if couchdb cluster nodes are ready. Of course we could just run `finish_cluster` action with `curl` in a loop until we get a desired result, I may try this to check if it looks better (and again, maybe contribute to upstream chart later?).

@amatas Alfredo, I have small update – I tried to install CouchDB using current Helm chart, but with `gpii/couchdiscover` as sidecar. Unfortunately it did not work :( Couchdiscover fails with the following error:
```Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/couchdiscover", line 11, in <module>

  File "/package/couchdiscover/kube.py", line 87, in _init_from_fqdn

  File "/package/couchdiscover/kube.py", line 81, in _split_node

ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)```

Sergey,

Your fixes for my comments look good, except I can't find the timeout (I commented above in the thread).

content.title: [GPII-3418]: Tune resource requests one more time
content.body:
This is the long-term solution I promised.

For dev clusters I had to keep requests lowered in order to stay on cheaper `n1-standard-2` nodes.

For staging / prod clusters:
* To have "more predictable" scheduling with requests = limits
* To also have more replicas of preferences, flowmanager and couchdb (similarly to AWS setup)
* And finally, to have enough room for rolling updates with `maxUnavailable: 0`

I suggest to use `n1-highcpu-4` instances. They are a bit cheaper than `n1-standard-4` and have significantly less RAM (4GB vs 15GB), but since we are very far away from hitting RAM limit, it seems like the most optimal choice in our situation.

Changing node type will most likely cause Terraform to attempt to recreate the cluster. I am not sure if there is a way around this issue for staging and prod, I am open to suggestions!

Using container_node_pool should improve this situation:
https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3419
comments: LGTM
LGTM

> value passed down as a parameter from each environment

+1

@stepanstipl @mrtyler Good point! Unfortunately, getting rid of env-based interpolations in modules requires adding more plumbing in order to pass variables from Terragrunt to Terraform and then into templates. But I also believe that it results in a bit more clear module code and more flexible per-environment configs.

Please review updated version!

LGTM

Thanks for re-plumbing those templated variables. I think the new form is easier to understand and more consistent with the Exekube/Terraform module model.

Thanks Sergey, I like the effort to make limits & requests same value 👍 

But I think the logic should not be hardcoded in this module, but rather the value passed down as a parameter from each environment -> that way we would avoid the hardcoded logic completely and have a bit more flexibility I believe.

Agree with the choice of instance size.

content.title: Various fixes
content.body:
This addresses the following issues that we're getting in CI:
* Fixes problems with leftover [locust task links](https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114182115) (GPII-3362).
* Adds retry block to workaround [internal Stackdriver error](https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114504326).
* Fixes problem with Stackdriver debug mode causing [failures during module destruction](https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114521169).
* Removes `|| true` from `rake destroy` after script for `common-stg-test-gcp-dev` and `gcp-dev`. This caused [multiple](https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114659791) [situations](https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114619178) when destroy task was interrupted due to some issue, but following after script task destroyed TF state, making Terraform think that there are no resources exist, requiring long and annoying process of manual resource cleanup.
* Improves couchdb module `finish_cluster` resource by removing unnecessary waits, cutting 20 secs off module execution time.

lgtm

https://gitlab.com/gpii-ops/gpii-infra/-/jobs/114521169

This change means that if `rake destroy` fails, then none of the subsequent commands will run. Skipping `rake destroy_say_keys` and `rake clobber` doesn't look right to me.

I proposed a different solution in https://issues.gpii.net/browse/GPII-3488.

I still think that the best course of action when `rake destroy` fails is to do nothing and leave things as they are, so we can investigate what happened. 

Agree that keeping TF state is crucial for this, but secrets data can also be pretty important. I guess we can still run `rake destroy_sa_keys` and `rake clobber` safely...

Does it look good to you if I replace `rake destroy || true` after script with `(rake destroy && rake destroy_tfstate[k8s] && rake destroy_secrets) || true`, so subsequent commands `rake destroy_tfstate[locust]`, `rake destroy_sa_keys`, `rake clobber` can still run?

> I still think that the best course of action when rake destroy fails is to do nothing and leave things as they are, so we can investigate what happened.

I think there is merit in this argument. The main counterargument I see is the cost of leaving a dev cluster running for N additional hours until someone investigates a failure or a new pipeline runs. It is possible that this cost is negligible and outweighed by the value of being able to investigate the cluster that produced the failed build. This topic may warrant further discussion.

If we choose to change this behavior we should add a `rake destroy` before a dev Job's initial `rake` so that it is deploying into a (hopefully) clean environment.

> replace rake destroy || true after script with (rake destroy && rake destroy_tfstate[k8s] && rake destroy_secrets) || true, so subsequent commands rake destroy_tfstate[locust], rake destroy_sa_keys, rake clobber can still run?

Yes, this is what I was proposing.

> The main counterargument I see is the cost of leaving a dev cluster running for N additional hours

If destroy task fails on some dependency of `k8s-cluster` module, cluster is left running and consuming resources anyway. 

> If we choose to change this behavior we should add a rake destroy before a dev Job's initial rake so that it is deploying into a (hopefully) clean environment.

I was thinking about that, but IMO, if `rake destroy` fails, chances that the failure is intermittent and going to be solved by another destroy without manual intervention are pretty low.

content.title: Adds WAF for IIIF apis (test/count only for now)
Tweak our BuildKite setup
content.body:
This change is already applied.

Currently nothing is running in CI because the spot price of the r5.large instances we use has just passed $0.04:

> Launching a new EC2 instance. Status Reason: Your Spot request price of 0.04 is lower than the minimum required Spot request fulfillment price of 0.0411. Launching EC2 instance failed.

Since this is only a small part of our bill ($72/mo), we can safely increase the spot bid without breaking the bank.

We also spent $126 last month on gp2 EBS volumes, most of which will be our BuildKite runners. I'm reasonably confident that we don't actually need 250GB per instance, so I've reduced it and added a check that will help us spot if a job failed due to low disk space.

content.title: Add some VPC endpoints for connecting to ECR
content.body:
For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4920 and https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4926

We spend ~$300/mo on NAT Gateway in the CI VPC, when almost everything it does is talking within AWS. We should be able to make this cost less spiky.

Also add the Name tags to as many endpoints as can be done from this repo, both for ease of working in the console and cost allocation purposes.

content.title: Add some lifecycle rules to the platform-infra bucket
content.body:
We shouldn't be keeping everything that goes in this bucket indefinitely. This is particularly driven by https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/5025, which will start adding 1GB+ snapshots of the Sierra data to this bucket, and we don't need to keep multiple copies of that.

Because this is a potentially destructive change, I'm not going to apply it until it's reviewed.
comments: A thought is that there are some terraform states that don't get updated for ages (platform-infrastructure). I don't think I can find a reason why this is a problem, but it just crossed my mind.

> A thought is that there are some terraform states that don't get updated for ages (platform-infrastructure). I don't think I can find a reason why this is a problem, but it just crossed my mind.

The useful time to roll back to a previous version of state is straight after something went wrong; I think it's very unlikely we'd want to roll back to state from more than three months ago.
What benefits do we get by going through this lifecycle over just expiring the versions?
Slightly lower costs, although tbh it's just copy/pasta from whatever example I got this from. I can remove it.

content.title: Manage the logging cluster in Terraform; connect to it using a VPC endpoint
content.body:
For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/5002

I didn't mean this to be quite so disruptive, but in for a penny, in for a pound.

This pull request adds a new Elasticsearch cluster for logging (`ec_deployment.logging`). It also adds traffic filters that allow it to receive traffic from every VPC into which we copy our shared logging secrets. These traffic filters are connected to VPC endpoints, which means logs can be sent cheaper than going over a managed NAT Gateway. It's a big diff, but a lot of it is repetition.

Next steps:

- [x] Get this cluster working with OIDC
- [x] Put this cluster behind logging.wellcomecollection.org
- [x] Set up index expiry for these logs, so we don't fill up the cluster's disk
comments: Phew! This is a big change - you've got it out neatly and v.quick too.
Useful comment.

content.title: Use VPC endpoints to talk to ECR in CI
content.body:
We spent ~$250/mo in NAT Gateway costs for CI; see [Cost Explorer](https://console.aws.amazon.com/cost-management/home?#/custom?excludeRIRecurringCharges=false&startDate=2021-02-20&excludeTax=false&excludeSupportCharges=false&endDate=2021-03-22&timeRangeOption=Custom&hasAmortized=false&excludeRIUpfrontFees=false&filter=%5B%7B%22dimension%22:%22Operation%22,%22values%22:%5B%22NatGateway%22%5D,%22include%22:true,%22children%22:null%7D%5D&isTemplate=true&groupBy=TagKeyValue:Name&forecastTimeRangeOption=None&excludeCredit=false&excludeTaggedResources=false&reportType=CostUsage&chartStyle=Line&granularity=Daily&excludeOtherSubscriptionCosts=false&hasBlended=false&excludeRefund=false&reportName=Daily%20API%20operation%20costs&excludeDiscounts=true&usageAs=usageQuantity&excludeCategorizedResources=false&excludeForecast=false)

A substantial part of this is likely to be sending Docker images to/from ECR – at $0.045/GB and ~200MB/application image, it stacks up. I'm hoping this bends the curve down a bit.

Tentatively closes https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/4920

content.title: Double the number of Buildkite instances at peak; reduce disk usage
content.body:
Last month we spent ~$75 on r5.large instances and ~$100 on gp2 volumes. Our BuildKite setup is also imbalanced:

* It's possible to max out our 30 workers. At peak build times, you can be waiting 20m+ for your build to start. Slow!
* 150GB is massive, a quick spin through our current worker pool suggests they have ~144GB or so free with a warm cache (this is logged as part of our pre-job hook). Wasteful!

This change tries to rebalance that spending: take some of the money we're spending on gp2 volumes, and spend it on running more workers instead. I don't expect it to impact the bill much, but it should avoid our builds getting throttled because too many people are building at once.

content.title: Cycle objects in the digitisation buckets to Standard-IA
Move the unhandled Miro images to Glacier Deep Archive
Add a monthly report for costs data in Slack
content.body:
For https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform/issues/5281

This adds a monthly report that tells us how much we're spending. It should fire on the second Tuesday of every month (i.e., next Tuesday, and then every month after that).

You probably want to start with the explanation in the README (https://github.com/wellcomecollection/platform-infrastructure/tree/costs-report/costs_report), then get to the code.

content.title: Reduce DFI Instances size for identified cost savings
ALS-2057 - Added configuration for LDAP EFS + reduced specs for root EBS volume
content.body: Provisioned IOPS is no longer required for the root volume, as the LDAP data is now hosted on EFS. This should result in an EBS cost reduction.
comments: LGTM

content.title: Dam 515
content.body: maded mpx and "all in one" host as per UKcloud, as a means to getting around the cert issue and also to save costs.
comments: Paul says it's alright

content.title: Add CPU-SMALL instances
content.body:
This adds a class of CPU instances that are far [cheaper](https://instances.vantage.sh/?compare_on=true&selected=c4.4xlarge,r5.large) than the current `CPU` instances that we can use for certain tasks that don't require big instances, I'm thinking for linting and builds (since those are mostly cached anyways). We could also potentially move certain test steps to these instances such as the unit tests but reliability.

cc @areusch @konturn
comments: @konturn thoughts?
This looks good--once we switch the relevant jobs over to this tag we can start profiling average usage and then get convertible RI's for this instance series.

content.title: Shuffle parameters for autoscaled nodes
content.body:
These couple changes should help get the job queue under control now
that we're using a lot more node-level parallelism. EBS costs are also up since every node is getting 250 GB which is more than it needs (spot checked a bunch of nodes, never saw more than 65 GB in use). Queue got pretty backed up yesterday

content.title: Add ARM-SMALL instance type
content.body:
Same as in #24 this adds `r6g.large` instances under the
`ARM-SMALL` label so we can start testing and using those in CI (5x
cheaper than `m6g.4xlarge`). If that works well we can convert some
usages over, and if not we can remove this autoscaling group.

cc @konturn @areusch
comments: lgtm--we'll have to run jenkins workflow in ci repo for the fleet change to be propagated of course.

content.title: Landing zone
content.body:
**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one with "x")

```
[ ] Yes
[X] No
```
comments: this may need changing to work in prod but let's see how we get on

this probably doesn't belong here? should be provisioned elsewhere?
```suggestion
data "azurerm_resource_group" "main" {
```

this should probably be default rules:
```suggestion
    name  = "default"
```
if a rule isn't specified is it enabled?

this should probably be:
```suggestion
    disabled_rules = {
```

```suggestion
frontends = [
```
yes, by default all rules are enabled.
yes, we can change this depending on how the cnames will be configured for production.

> this probably doesn't belong here? should be provisioned elsewhere?

nope. I dsagree. The landing zone should be kept entirely separate to all the other resources. Hence we should keep all the resources that constitutes the landing zone to be in one resource group. However this resource group should not be used by any other resources. Hence the name of the resource group will not be available as an output.

what if the service principal doesn't have permissions to create the resource group though?
we've been moving away from subscription level permissions to resource group level permissions to limit the blast radius from mistakes, and reduce 'god' level permissions

> this should probably be default rules:

There are no default rules. Each frontend will be created with its own WAF policy. This is to segregate each application and also to enable teams/applications to configure there own waf rules independently. Azure supports that. If a team has no disabled rules then the waf policy for that frontend/team will have all the rules enabled as a default configuration.

does a waf policy cost anything?
was just wondering if we should have a default almost everything on policy that apps could use

Yes, there is a cost associated with WAF.  Monthly charges per unit and request based charges. https://azure.microsoft.com/en-gb/pricing/details/frontdoor/
It would be good (cost-wise) if we can have 1 policy that is adhered by all the application frontends but that needs to be finalized by secops and also the teams.

I think it would probably be clearer to just have the full host name here. Prod domains get very specially named domains. The other environments can be done via convention like this but it won’t work in prod.

Can’t you just do .terraform
Shouldn’t need the *s plus the following line
`*tfplan*` should cover all variations
It is required with the folder structure targetted with the repository.

1. tfplan is just the name of the output file that we use with the terraform plan command. Doesn't necessary need to be just tfplan. 
2. The folder structure that is targetted with this repository will require the gitignore file to be created.
This will be used with the CI/CD that will be created later

```suggestion
*tfplan*
```

I think this should work?
```suggestion
.terraform/
```

1. Prod domains will be in the prod tfvar file. This is not for prod.  
2. The way it is designed is you can any type of domain in the respective environment file. for prod you can have 

`backend_domain` = ["xyz.abc.co.uk"]

content.title: packet: Add support for reservation_ids on workers
content.body:
High level description of the change.

* This patch allows to use packet `hardware_reservation_id` on worker pools.

This is an example of how it can be used:

```
module "worker" {
 ...
  cluster_name = "cluster"
  pool_name = "test"
  count = 3
  reservation_ids = {
    worker-0 = "some-reservation-id"
    worker-2 = "some-other-reservation-id"
  }
 ...
}
```
This will create a worker pool with 3 nodes, the hostnames are: `cluster-test-worker-0`, `cluster-test-worker-1`, `cluster-test-worker-2`.

The `reservation_ids` map only uses the `worker` prefix and the index, so to assign a `hardware_reservation_id` to the first worker of the pool you use `worker-0 = "..."`. No matter the cluster nor pool name. This, of course, can be changed if you think it is better to do it in some other way.

Nodes that are not in the map will not use a `hardware_reservation_id`. The reason for this is twofold, but I'm very open to sugguestions as there are not strong reasons:

 * Sometimes you want to reserve some nodes, and add/remove on overflow. Having to c&p a worker pool doesn't sound appealing for that use case (although is not that bad either)

 * The code might be slightly more complicated if we want to enforce a worker pool to either use on all nodes a `hardware_reservation_id` or not use it on any node. And I don't see a good reason to enforce it, so I opted for simpler code (but, again, I might be missing the reson todo it :))

What do you think?

## Testing

Tested with and without a reservation_id, for all or some of the nodes, and changing it for living nodes. It all worked fine, although I didn't use a valid `hardware_reservation_id` (so it just failed that it didn't exist). Tomorrow will try to get one and test with a valid reservation id too.

UPDATE: tried with a reservation id, it works as expected :)
comments: LGTM.
LGTM

@invidian @indradhanush another thing to take into account is that the hardware-reservation-id can be set to `next-available` too. So, another way to model this up is to have the worker pool only with reservation ids and "next-available" as default (although not sure it is a good default).

I think it also makes sense to keep it like it is in the PR (nodes not in the map don't use a reservation id) and, even if you want to use 'next-available', you can set that on the reservation_id map for each node.

But if you want to enforce nodes to have a reservation id (to make sure you are not paying on demand instead of a discount price), you can't with this approach. This is the main disadvantaje I see to the PR as it is. And I'm not sure it is an issue on the real world (i.e. a user actually needs this) or just theoretical.

IMHO, let's keep it like this unless a good use case to change this is reported.

Hmm, it seems that `next-available` is not documented in API docs. It does appear in the article though.

What about making a default configurable then? We set it to `""` by default, but user should be able to change it to `next-available`.

What happens if you don't have reserved hardware anymore and you try to create device with `next-available`? Will it fail?

EDIT: also just found this now: https://github.com/cncf/cnf-testbed/issues/215

I don't feel `next-available` would be a good default as it seems to presume that most users of Packet would want that behaviour by default, whereas we don't have any way to be sure. I'd be comfortable leaving the default to `""`.

> Hmm, it seems that `next-available` is not documented in API docs. It does appear in the article though.
> 
> What about making a default configurable then? We set it to `""` by default, but user should be able to change it to `next-available`.

I did a patch for this too, but I'm not sure this is useful (asked a client to gather input too). I lean towards just "", as if there is a good use case, we can just add the variable in a backwards-compatible way (i.e. add a variable  `reservation_id_default` that can be set, but it's default value is "").

Therefore, I don't see the need to add that now.

> EDIT: also just found this now: [cncf/cnf-testbed#215](https://github.com/cncf/cnf-testbed/issues/215)

Thanks! So, we can probably not use this until it is fixed and useful, then :)

Updated PR description to add that I tested with a real reservation now (all went fine).

> What happens if you don't have reserved hardware anymore and you try to create device with `next-available`? Will it fail?

Yes, `terraform apply` fails with `* packet_device.nodes.1: There are no available hardware reservations for selected plan and facility`.

IMHO, the best path is to keep the PR (keeping in mind also the reasons here: https://github.com/kinvolk/lokomotive-kubernetes/pull/5#issuecomment-495207900)

@indradhanush @invidian What do you think?
I wonder if it's a good idea to link to the docs on reserved hardware i.e. https://support.packet.com/kb/articles/reserved-hardware here.

Good point, will add it!

Do you think here only, right? Or in variables.tf too? (seems too long for there, IMHO)
@indradhanush If the updated doc seems okay, please resolve the conversation :)

content.title: Prisoner content hub - prod - Upgrade RDS to t3.xlarge
content.body:
This is to increase the resources for RDS to `xlarge`, as we are seeing errors in RDS related to max_connections.  E.g. 
```
2022-07-22 13:11:39 0 [Warning] Aborted connection 0 to db: 'unconnected' user: 'unauthenticated' host: 'connecting host' (Too many connections)
```

The max_connections configuration is tied to the db instance size.

Note we are **not** increasing the dev and staging environments, as these do not require such a large instance and would be an unnecessary cost.

Related Trello card: https://trello.com/c/EjfBYww7/1315-downtime-post-mortem

content.title: INC-964: Increase Incentives prod DB instance class
content.body:
Changed DB instance class to `db.t4g.large`.

Also:
- added deletion protection
- added backup/maintenance window
- added explicit `allow_minor_version_upgrade = true` (this was already the case because of the [TF module default](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-terraform-rds-instance#input_allow_minor_version_upgrade) for this value)

### Downtime
The [module has `apply_immediately = true `](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-terraform-rds-instance/blob/64a95b9785d72009ec979a52053cd1400effa8c8/main.tf#L110) which means once this is merged the change will be applied straight away.

The backup/maintenance window are added for other/future automated changes (e.g. minor version upgrades or patching)

The [module configures the database as a Multi-AZ](https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-terraform-rds-instance/blob/64a95b9785d72009ec979a52053cd1400effa8c8/main.tf#L124) DB instance deployment.
This means that the downtime should be limited to the time of the failover, possibly a minute or two.
[See AWS RDS documentation](https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/rds-mysql-downtime-impact/#Updating_the_DB_instance_class) (page is for MySQL but process should be the same)

#### Multi-AZ deployment
In a Multi-AZ deployment AWS keeps another DB instance in standby in a different Availability Zone (AZ).
This is not normally used but is kept in sync with the Primary.

If there is a problem with the Primary instance/AZ the Standby can "failover" and become the Primary. This can take a few seconds/minutes and this can cause downtime.

The same approach is used when changing the instance class:
1. The Standby instance is modified first (no downtime as this is not used)
2. The Standby causes a "failover" becoming the Primary instance (during this switch there is a brief downtime)
3. The old Primary instance is now the Standby instance (not used)
4. The change is applied to this instance too

…because it's a bit more performant and cheaper. plus, it's likely to have a longer pg version upgrade path
FYI: Done here: https://github.com/ministryofjustice/cloud-platform-environments/pull/10462/commits/4a573f9b79987523e8fa1e9fff2b46f3bf81d0ba

We have decided on `db.m5.large` as the T3 instance class is burstable and we wanted consistency

Additionally, the m5.large has 2 cpu, 8 GB RAM as well as the t3.large but more bandwidth and better network performance in exchange for about 25% increase in cost

For the load around July 2021, we had quite a lot of data going back and forth for dashboard queries, so we wanted consistent load and bandwidth guarantees.

content.title: Update low CPU alarm on ECS tasks
content.body:
### What

* Reduce low CPU alarm threshold to 0.3% on staging Auth API and Logging API ECS task alarms.
* Toggle CPU threshold value to adjust for different CPU averages between staging and production.
* Update alarm name and description for clarity

### Why

* The average CPU for both staging ECS tasks is always below 1% (even the max CPU rarely exceeds 1%) therefore these alerts will always go off. The minimum low CPU hovers around 0.3%, in which case we do want to downscale the number of ECS tasks for efficiency and cost savings.
* Production is slightly different. The CPU average rarely dips below 1% so it's sensible to keep the threshold for production at 1%.

[Link to Trello card](https://trello.com/c/XowCI6x0/298-address-cloudwatch-alerts-in-alarm-state).

content.title: Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana
content.body:
### What

Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana. This enables the data for Prometheus, and the Grafana configuration to be recovered if the volumes or instances are deleted. The snapshots are created and managed using Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager, which incurs no extra cost (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/snapshot-lifecycle.html).

### Why

It is best practice to have a backup of our data

content.title: feat: add an S3 bucket to collect metrics

# Description
We want a new S3 bucket for our apps to write custom metrics intro, and for us to consume through another app later.

# Discussion
Am I right in thinking that this is enough to get us going? A simple S3 bucket built on the London side of the cloud, namescoped to the correct environment.

When we actually want to write or read in it, we'll simply specify the bucket name in the relevant IAM policies (i.e `govwifi-admin/iam-roles.tf`)?

Please test in staging before moving to production.

Also, am I wrong in thinking that if the bucket and its roles are declared in Terraform, the dashboard instance should also live in there? i.e how do we access the bucket's read policy once our env is terraformed?

Hi @freesteph 

> Robin Mitra I cannot figure out where to add the correct IAM roles. govwifi-backend seems to be the right place to have this bucket dealt with but then I don't think the govwifi-admin folder inherits any of it even though it should also write in there.

I'd suggest moving dashboard specific resources into its own module (like how it's been done for `govwifi-admin`, for example), in order to keep everything related to the dashboard in one place.

> Ideally I would have written two separate named roles for writing and reading into the metrics bucket but that doesn't seem to be the pattern. Also unsure how to merge these back in the current roles. Pointers appreciated!

It's okay to think about roles in terms of the user of the role (e.g. "metric-recorder" role would allow reading and writing operations, because that's what the metric recorder user would need in order to do its job), rather than the atomic operations the role permits.

> Also, am I wrong in thinking that if the bucket and its roles are declared in Terraform, the dashboard instance should also live in there? i.e how do we access the bucket's read policy once our env is terraformed?

If we are to host the dashboard on PaaS then don't think we can declare it here. PaaS does support [S3 backing](https://docs.cloud.service.gov.uk/deploying_services/s3/#amazon-s3), so we'll need to figure out how to grant permission to the PaaS app to access the bucket.
did you `terraform fmt`? i still see many changes when i do that in this branch. i do appreciate that people were not doing it because other files you didn't touch are modified too.
Hey @fredericfran-gds, thanks for the review! I haven't ran `terraform-fmt` as ran into some issues just getting TF to run. Do we commit the changes and then deploy or the other way around?
So that linting process (I wasn't aware terraform had linting) hasn't yielded any issues.

2. terraform plan it and show me the results. 
3. I approve it after all the changes are ok and terraform plan works.
Morning @fredericfran-gds . I've successfully deployed the bucket to staging on S3. Can I deploy to production and merge this?
yes this is fine. Thanks.
I was going to suggest to lowercase this, but going to accept this as there seems to be some sort of convention around this in the existing code 🤷‍♂️
Well I take it back, as there are some modules which do declare it in lowercase (e.g. `sns-notification`), so it isn't consistent anyway. So I'd suggest lowercasing it.
I'd suggest moving it to `outputs.tf` within the module.

content.title: Initial setup of kubernetes cluster
content.body: This sets up a plain kubernetes cluster in the MDN AWS account
comments: As for the parts that I understand, they look good to me, and I can see that you've already spun-up the single-AZ, single-master cluster. Thanks @limed!
Cluster moved to us-west-2a apologies for the huge commits

Note as a side effect of only creating 1 cluster in 1 AZ this happens:

```
* aws_db_subnet_group.rds: Error creating DB Subnet Group: DBSubnetGroupDoesNotCoverEnoughAZs: DB Subnet Group doesn't meet availability zone coverage requirement. Please add subnets to cover at least 2 availability zones. Current coverage: 1
```

I suspect the previous setup had an existing VPC with multiple AZ and new clusters were just setup in a singular AZ with existing VPC. So basically this means that we have to create the VPC first in multiple AZ (using something like terraform or awscli) and then have kops create the cluster in the single AZ
For now additional subnets have been created manually
nice work, thanks @limed!

As I've mentioned before in our meetings, it is my recommendation to run each cluster in a separate AZ, and not to spread a single cluster across multiple AZs. http://docs.heptio.com/content/aws-qs-multi-az.html gives some additional background and makes the same recommendation.
After discussing with @jwhitlock yesterday he mentioned he was ok with this setup for now.

Thanks for that heptio link @jgmize! @jwhitlock will make the final decision here, but based on the heptio recommendation, it seems that for now, perhaps we should go with a single AZ cluster with a single master (which is what we have now), and then we're poised to add HA later. @limed I don't think it would be that difficult to tear down the current cluster and spin-up a new one in a single AZ (with a single master), right?

No its easy for me to tear it down and bring the cluster back up. As long as I have a definitive decision then I can do whatever is needed. The current configuration is just based off the conversation we had the day before

My go-ahead yesterday was based on my limited understanding of the issue, and the perception that losing a master node was difficult to recover from (which I think @jgmize talked about, but maybe that was losing the etcd cluster). I find the Heptio article pretty convincing in arguing against aiming for high-availability in the master node, but instead on automating master recovery.

I read the linked [Kubernes Federation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/federation/) docs, which seem to describe the 3 master + 3 node configuration, but also suggest "maybe don't use Federation v1, wait for Federation v2, and don't ask us when v2 will ship".

Under "Scope of a single cluster":

> We suggest that all the VMs in a Kubernetes cluster should be in the same availability zone, because:
> * compared to having a single global Kubernetes cluster, there are fewer single-points of failure.
> * compared to a cluster that spans availability zones, it is easier to reason about the availability properties of a single-zone cluster.
> * when the Kubernetes developers are designing the system (e.g. making assumptions about latency, bandwidth, or correlated failures) they are assuming all the machines are in a single data center, or otherwise closely connected.

It seems that spreading nodes over several availability zones is going to have a negative impact on run-time performance, for questionable availability benefits. *sigh*.

@limed I'd like your opinion again after reading those articles, and I'm sorry if my approval sent you down the wrong path.
@limed Perhaps we should go immediately with `KOPS_NODE_COUNT=10` to match the current MozMEAO cluster, or would you prefer to increase it later when I spin-up the production instance of MDN?

We can set it 10 but mozmeao has other apps running in the cluster does MDN require all 10? I'm fine with whatever the number here but just reminder of the cost of 10x m4.large. Also I'm making an assumption that stage and prod will be on the same cluster and separated  based on kubernetes namespaces, am I right to assume this?

I agree, let's stick with 3 for now. I think adding a new node is easy, and staging is less than 10 pods.

I'd like to work w/ @jgmize or @metadave to figure out the load in our current cluster. We're probably not using the capabilities of 10 nodes at the moment, but with reserved instances we haven't been under as much pressure to reduce it.
The MozMEAO cluster that MDN currently uses does not host any other apps. It's only used for MDN stage and production. You're right that stage and prod are separated by Kubernetes namespaces.

I read the article and the article states

> Heptio’s recommended solution is to run a separate cluster in each Availability Zone

Which we are not planning on doing this time around, ultimately if we choose to run a single cluster on a single AZ I'm going to point out that in an event that the AZ has an outage the entire cluster goes down (Until we stand up a multi cluster single AZ setup)

AWS in generally recommends splitting things in up into multiple AZ which is why I myself would always prefer to have multi AZ single cluster. However when we do manage to get the time to setup a multi cluster single AZ setup I would be happy to follow the recommendation of the article.

Ultimately I can be swayed both ways, but if the choice is to go single AZ single cluster then I will point out that if the AZ has an outage you might lose the entire cluster

> The MozMEAO cluster that MDN currently uses does not host any other apps
I stand corrected :)

But yeah I'm ok with bumping up the number of nodes but for now lets keep it to 3

> @limed I think I was wrong yesterday, and we should switch to a single-master, single-availability zone cluster for the staging work. There's some open questions about expanding from there (stage and prod in same cluster? second cluster in the same region? fallback cluster in a new region), but I hope we can get unstuck on CI tasks with the single cluster for staging.

Ok single cluster with single AZ it is, I don't think there are remaining questions about stage on prod since they will remain in the same cluster (They will be separated by namespaces). I don't believe we will be stuck for CI tasks if its a single cluster. The only complication for me will be when we start having multiple clusters in single AZ's since I have no experience in this setup. At that point I will just bug @jgmize to help me with that setup :)
Note that with https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/tree/master/cluster-autoscaler we can start with 3 and new nodes will be provisioned automatically as necessary.
